editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE PHOENIX, AS It hath beene ſundry times Acted by the Children of Paules, And preſented before his Maieſtie.
LONDON Printed by E.A. for A, I, and are to be ſolde at the ſigne of the white horſe in Paules-Churchyard. 1607.

div.head: THE Phoenix:
div.stage: Enter the old Duke of Ferrara, Nobles, Proditor, Luſsurioſo, and Infeſto, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du
sp.l: MY Lordes,
Know that we far from any naturall pride
Or touch of temporall ſway, haue ſeene our face
In our graue counſels foreheads: where doth ſtand
Our trueſt glaſſe, made by Times wrinckled hand.
We know wee're old, my daies proclayme me ſo:
Fortie-fiue yeres, I'ue gently ruld this Dukedome,
Pray heauen it be no fault,
For there's as much diſeaſe, though not to th' eye,
In too much pittie, as in Tyrannie.

sp.speaker: Infeſt.
sp.l: Your grace hath ſpoke it right.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I know that life
Has not long courſe in me, twill not be long
Before I ſhow that Kinges haue mortall bodies
As well as Subjects, therefore to my comfort,
And your ſucceſfull hopes I haue a Sonne
Whome I dare boaſt of;—

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Whome we all do boaſt off,
A Prince elder in vertues then in yeares,

sp.speaker: Infeſt.
sp.l: His iudgement is a Father to his youth,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I, I, would he were from Court,

sp.speaker: Infeſt.
sp.l: Our largeſt hopes grow in him,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: And tis the greateſt pittie Noble Lord,
He is vntraueld,

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Tis indeede my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Had he but trauaile to his time and Vertue—oh hee ſhould neere returne agen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo, what is in hope begun,
Experience quickens, trauaile confirmes the man,
Who's elſe liues doubtfull, and his daies oft ſorye,
"Who's rich in Knowledge, ha's the ſtocke of glorye.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Moſt true my royall Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Some one attend our Sonne.

sp.speaker: Infeſt.
sp.l: See, heere hee comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Oh you come well.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Tis alwaies my deſire my worthy Father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your Serious ſtudyes, & thoſe fruitfull howres
That grow vp into iudgement, well become
Your birth, and all our loues: I weepe that you are my ſonne,
But Vertuouſly I weepe, the more my gladnes:
We haue thought good and meete by the conſent
Of theſe our Nobles, to moue you toward Trauaile,
The better to approue you to your ſelfe
And giue your apter power, foundation:
To ſee affections actually praeſented,
Ee'n by thoſe men that owe them, yeeld more profit,
I more content, then ſingly to reade of them,
"Since loue or feare, make Writers partiall,
The good and free example which you finde,
In other Countries, match it with your owne,
The ill to ſhame the ill, which will in time,
Fully inſtruct you how to ſet in frame,
A kingdome all in peeces.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Honoured Father,
With care and duetie I haue liſtned to you,
What you deſire, in me it is obedience,
I doe obey in all, knowing for right,
"Experience is a Kingdomes better ſight.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Oh tis the verie luſtre of a Prince,
Trauaile! tis ſweete and generous,

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: He that knowes how to obey, knowes how to reigne
And that true knowledge haue we found in you,
Make choice of your Attendants.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Theyr ſoone choſe, only this man my Lord, a louing ſeruant of mine.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What none but he?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I doe intreate no more,
For that's the benefit a priuate Gentleman
Enioyes beyond our ſtate, when he notes all,
Himſelfe vnnoted,
For ſhould I beare the faſhion of a prince,
I ſhould then win more flatterie, then profit,
And I ſhould giue e'm time & warning then
To hide their Actions from me, if I appeare a Sunne,
Theile run into the ſhade with their ill deedes,
And ſo preuent me.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A little too wiſe, a little too wiſe to liue long.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: You haue anſwered vs with wiſdome, let it be.
Things priuate are beſt known through priuacy.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Stay you my elected ſeruant.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My kinde Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The Duke my Father has a heauy burthen,
Of yeares vpon him.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My Lord it ſeemes ſo, for they make him ſtoope.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Without diſſemblance hee is deepe in age,
He bowes vnto his graue, I wonder much
Which of his wilde Nobilitie it ſhould bee
(For none of his ſad counſell has a voyce in't)
Should ſo farre trauaile into his conſent,
To ſet me ouer into other Kingdomes.
Vpon the ſtroke and minute of his death?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My Lord, tis eaſier to ſuſpect them all,
Then truly to name one.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Since it is thus,
By abſence, ile obey the Duke my father,
And yet not wrong my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: Therein my Lord,
You might be happie twice.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: So it ſhall bee,
Ile ſtay at home, and trauaile;

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Would your Grace
Could make that good.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I can, & indeed a Prince need no trauaile farther then his owne Kingdome, if hee applie himſelfe faythfullye, worthie the glorie of himſelfe and expectation of others: and it would appeare farre nobler induſtrie in him, to reforme thoſe faſhions that are alreadye in his Countrey, then to bring newe ones in, which haue neither true forme nor faſhion; to make his Court an Owle, Cittie an Ape, and the Countrey a Wolfe, preying vpon the ridiculous pride of eyther, and therefore I holde it a ſafer ſterne vpon this luckie aduantage, ſince my father is nere his ſetting, and I vpon the Eaſterne hil to take my riſe, to look into the heart & bowels of this Dukedome, and in diſguiſe, marke all abuſes readie for Reformation or Puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Giue me but leaue vnfainedly to admire you,
Your wiſdome is ſo ſpacious and ſo honeſt,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p:
So much haue the complaints and ſuits of men, ſeauen, nay ſeauenteene yeares neglected, ſtil interpoſd by coine and great enemies, preuaild with my pittie, that
I cannot otherwiſe thinke but there are infectious dealings in moſt offices, and foule miſteries throughout al Profeſſions: and therefore I nothing doubt but to find trauaile ynough within my ſelfe, and Experience I fear too much: nor will I be curious to fit my bodie to the humbleſt forme and bearing, ſo the labor may be fruitfull: for how can abuſes that keepe lowe, come to the right view of a Prince, vnleſſe his lookes lie leuell with them, which elſe will be longeſt hid from him, hee ſhall be the laſt man ſees 'em.
sp.l: For oft betwene Kings Eyes, and ſubiects Crimes
Stands there a barre of brybes, the vnder office
Flatters him next aboue it: he the next,
And ſo of moſt, or manye, Euerie Abuſe will chuſe a brother,
Tis through the world, this Hand will rub the other.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: You haue ſet downe the worlde briefly my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: But how am I aſſur'd of faith in thee?
Yet I durſt truſt thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Let my ſoule be loſt,
sp.p: When it ſhall looſe your ſecrets: nor will I onely bee a preſeruer of them, but if you ſo pleaſe an aſſiſter.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: It ſuffices:
That King ſtands ſur'ſt who by his vertue riſes
More then by birth or blood, that Prince is rare,
Who ſtriues in youth to ſaue his age from care,
Let's be preparde away.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ile follow your Grace,
Thou wonder of all Princes, Preſident, and Glorie,
True Phoenix, made of an vnuſuall ſtraine,
"Who labours to reforme is fit to raigne.
How can that King be ſafe that ſtudies not
The profite of his people? See where comes
The beſt part of my heart, my loue.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound to find you, I heard newly
Of ſuddaine Trauaile which his grace intends
And onely but your ſelfe to accompany him.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: You heard in that, little beſide the truth,
Yet not ſo ſuddaine as to want thoſe manners,
To leaue you vnregarded.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I did not thinke, ſo vnfaſhionably of you:
How long is your returne?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Tis not yet come to me, ſcarce to my Lord,
Vnleſſe the Duke referre it to his pleaſure,
But long I thinke it is not, the Dukes age,
(If not his apt experience) will forbid it.

sp.speaker: Neec.
sp.l: His grace commaunds, I muſt not think amiſſe, farwell

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Nay ſtay, and take this comfort,
You ſhall heare often from vs, ile direct
Where you ſhall ſurely knowe, and I deſire you
Write me the Truth, how my new father in lawe, the
Captaine beares himſelfe toward my Mother,
For that marriage, knew nothing of my minde,
It neuer flouriſht in any part of my affection.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Me thinkes ſha's much diſgrac'd herſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Nothing ſo: if he be good & wil abide the touch, a Captaine may marrie a Lady, if hee can ſaile into her good will.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Indeede thats all,

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Tis al in al, commend me to thy breſt, farwel.
So by my Lords firme pollicy we may ſee,
To preſent view, what abſent formes would be.

div.stage: Enter the Captaine with Souldiering fellowes.

sp.l: There's Noble purchaſe Captaine.
Nay admirable purchaſe.
Ynough to make vs proud for euer.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Hah?
Neuer was opportunitie ſo Gallant.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why you make me madde.
Three Ships not a poope leſſe.

sp.p: And euerieone ſo wealthily burdned vpon my manhood.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Pox on't, and now am I tyed ee'n as the Deuil would ha't.
Captaine, of all men liuing I wold ha' ſworne thou wouldſt nere haue married.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: S'foot, ſo would I my ſelfe man, giue mee my Due, you know I ha ſworne all heauen ouer and ouer:

sp.l: That you haue y faith.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why goe too then.

sp.p: Of a man that has taſted ſalt water to commit ſuch a freſh Tricke.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why tis abhominable I grant you now I ſee't:
Had there beene fewer Women—
And among thoſe Women fewer Drabs—
And among thoſe Drabs fewer pleaſing—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Then t'ad beene ſomething:

sp.p: But when there are more women, more common pretty ſweete hearts, then euer any age could boaſt off.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And I to play the Artificer and marrie: to haue my wife daunce at home, and my Ship at Sea, and both take in ſalt water together: oh Leiftenant thou'rt happie, thou keepſt a Wench.
I hope I am happyer then ſo Captaine, for a my Troth ſhee keepes me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: How? is there anye ſuch fortunate man breathing? and I ſo miſerable to liue honeſt? I enuie thee Lieutenant, I enuie thee, that thou art ſuch a happye Knaue, heres my hand among you, ſhare it equally, Ile to ſea with you.

sp.l: There ſpoke a Noble Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Lets heare from you, there will be newes ſhortly.
Doubt it not Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
What luſtfull paſſion came aboord of mee, that
I ſhould marrye, was I drunke? yet that cannot altogether holde, for it was foure a clocke 'ith morning, had it beene fiue, I would ha ſworne it: that a man is in danger euerie minute to be caſt away, without hee haue an extraordinarie Pilot that can performe more then a man can doe: and to ſay truth too, when 'ime abroad what can I doe at home? no man liuing can reach ſo farre: & what a horrible thing t'would bee to haue hornes brought me at Sea, to looke as if the Deuill were 'ith ſhip: and all the greate Tempeſtes would bee thought of my Rayſing, to bee the generall curſſe of all Merchants: and yet they likely are as deepe in as my ſelfe, and thats a comfort: O that a Captaine ſhould liue to be marryed! nay, I that haue beene ſuch a Gallant ſalt-theefe, ſhould yet liue to be marryed: What a fortunate Elder Brother is he, whoſe father being a Ramiſh Plough-man, himſelfe a perfumde Gentleman, ſpending the labouring reeke from his Fathers: Noſthrils in Tobacco: the ſweate of his Fathers bodye in monthlye Phiſickc for his pretty queſie Harlot: he ſowes a pace 'ith Countrie: the Taylor oretakes him i'th Cittie, ſo that often times before the Corne comes to Earning, tis vp to the eares in high Collars, and ſo at euerie harueſt the Reapers take paines for the Mercers, ha! why this is ſtirring happineſſe indeede, would my father had held a plow ſo, and fed vpon ſqueaz'd Curds and Onions, that I might haue bath'd inſenſualitie: but hee was too ruttiſh himſelfe to let me thriue vnder him, canſumde me before hee got me, & that makes me ſo wretched, now to be ſhackled with a wife, & not greatly rich neither.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Captaine, my Huſband.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: S'life call me husband agen, & ile play the Captaine and beate you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What ha's diſturb'd you ſir, that you now looke ſo like an Enemie vpon me?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Goe make a Widdower, hang thy ſelfe,
How comes it that you are ſo oppoſite
To loue and kindenes? I deſerue more Reſpect,
But that you pleaſe to be forgetfull of it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For loue to you, did I neglect my ſtate,
Chide better fortunes from me,
Gaue the world talke, laide all my friendes at waſte.

sp.speaker: Captaine.
sp.l: The more foole you, could you like none but me?
Could none but I ſupplye you?
I am ſure you were ſued to▪ by far worthyer men,
Deeper in wealth and Gentrie.
What couldſt thou ſee in me, to make thee doate ſo on me,
sp.p: If I knowe, I am a Villaine: what a torments this? why didſt thou marry me? you thinke as moſt of your inſatiate Widdowes, that Captaines can doe wonders, when 'laſſe the name do's often proue the better man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That which you vrge, ſhould rather giue me cauſe to repent then your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Then to that end I doo't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What a miſerable ſtate am I led into?

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: How now ſir?

sp.speaker: Seruus:
sp.l: Count Proditer is now alighted.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What, my Lord: I muſt make much of him, heele one day write me Cuckold: tis good to make much of ſuch a man, ee'n to my face, hee plyes it hard I thanke him:—
what, my worthy Lord!

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Ile come to you in order Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: Oh thats in order: a kiſſe is the Gammoth to prickſong.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Let me ſalute you Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: My deere eſteemed Count, I haue a life for you:

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Heare you the newes?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What may it be my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: My Lord, the Dukes Sonne is vpon his trauaile to ſeuerall Kingdomes.

sp.speaker: Cap,
sp.p: May it bee poſſible my Lord, and yet ſo little rumord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Tak't of my Truth, nay, twa's well manag'd, thinges are as they are handled: but all my care is ſtill, pray heauen hee returne ſafe, without danger Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why, is there any doubt to bee had of that my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I by my faith Captaine.
Princes haue priuate enemies, and great:
Put caſe a man ſhould grudge him, for his Vertues:
Or enuie him, for his wiſdome: why you know
This makes him lye bare breſted to his foe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: That's ful of certaintie my Lord, but who be his Attendants?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Thence Captaine comes the feare, but ſinglie attended neither (my beſt gladnes) only by your Sonne in Law Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Is it to be beleeu'd? I promiſe you my Lord then I beginne to feare him my ſelfe, that fellow will vndoe him: I durſt vndertake to corrupt him with twelue pence ouer and aboue, and thats a ſmall matter: ha's a whoriſh Conſcience, hee's an inſeperable Knaue, and I could neere ſpeake well of that fellow.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: All wee of the younger houſe, I can tell you do doubt him much,—the Ladyes remoou'd, ſhall we haue your ſweete ſoſcietie Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Though it bee in mine owne houſe, I deſire I may follow your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I loue to auoide ſtrife,
Not many monthes Phoenix ſhall keepe his life.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: So, his way is in, he knowes it,
We muſt not be vncurteous to a Lord,
sp.p: Warne him our houſe t'were vilde: his preſence is an honour, if he lie with our wiues, tis for our credite, wee ſhall be the better truſted, tis a ſigne wee ſhall liue ith world: O Tempeſts and Whirlewinds (who but that man whom the forefinger cannot daunt, that makes his ſhame his liuing:) Who but that man I ſay, could endure to be throughly married? Nothing but a diuorce can relieue me: any way to be rid of her would rid my torment: if all meanes faile Ile kil, or poyſon her, and purge my fault at ſea: but firſt Ile make gentle Trie of a Diuorce: But how ſhal I accuſe her ſubtle honeſtie? Ile attach this Lords comming to her, take hold of that: ask counſell: and now I remember, I haue acquaintance with an olde craftie Client, who by the puzzle of ſuites & ſhifting of Courts, has more tricks & ſtarting holes, then the dizzie pates of fifteene Atturneys: one that has beene muzled in Law like a Beare, and lead by the Ring of his ſpectacles from office to office: him Ile ſeeke out with haſte, all paths Ile tread,
sp.l: All deathes Ile die ere I die married.

div.stage: Enter Proditor with the Captaines wife.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Puh, you doe reſiſt me hardly.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I beſeech your Lordſhip ceaſe in this,
sp.p: Tis neuer to be grāted: if you come as a friend vnto my honour and my husband, you ſhall be euer welcome, if not, I muſt intreate it—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Why aſſure your ſelfe, Madame, tis not the faſhion.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Tis more my griefe my Lord, ſuch as my ſelfe are iudg'd the worſe for ſuch.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Faith y' are too nice, youle ſee me kindly forth:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And honourably welcome.

stage.hi: Enter a Groome before Phoenix, and Fidelio, alighting into an Inne.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: Gentlemen, y' are moſte neately welcome.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Y' are very cleanelye Sir, prethee haue a care to our Geldings.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: Your Geldings ſhall be well conſidered.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Conſidered?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sirha, what Gueſſe do's this Inne holde now?

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: Some fiue and twentie Gentlemen beſides their beaſtes.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Their Beaſtes?

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.p: Their wenches I meane ſir, for your worſhip I nowes thoſe that are vdder men are beaſtes.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How do's your Mother ſit?

sp.speaker: Groo.
sp.l: Verie well in health I thanke you heartily ſir.

sp.speaker: Phoe .
sp.l: And ſo is my Mare y faith.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: Ile doe her commendations indeede ſir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Well kept vp Shuttle-cocke:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But what olde fellow was he that newly alighted before vs?

sp.speaker: Gro.
sp.p: Who he? as arrant a craftie fellow as ere made water on horſebacke: ſome ſay hee's as good as a Lawyer, (marrie 'ime ſure hee's as bad as a Knaue) if you haue any ſuites in lawe, hee's the fitteſt man for your companie: ha's beene ſo▪ toward and lug'd himſelfe▪ that hee is able to affoo • d you more knauiſh counſell for tenne groates, then another for ten ſhillings.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: A fine fellowe: but doe you know him to be a Knaue, and will lodge him.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p:
Your worſhip begins to talke idlely, your bed ſhall be made preſently; if we ſhould not lodge knaues, I wonder how we ſhould bee able to liue honeſtlye, are there honeſt men enough thinke you in a Terme time to fill all the Innes in the towne, and as far as I can ſee▪ a knaues Gelding eats no more hay then an honeſt mans: nay theeues Gelding eates leſſe, ile ſtād too't, his Maiſter
allowes him a better Ordnarie: yet I haue my eightpe • ce day & night, twere more for our profit I wus, you were all theeues, if you were ſo contented: I ſhall bee cald for: giue your worſhips good morrow.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A royall knaue y faith: wee haue hapned into a Godly Inne.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Aſſure you my L. they belong al to one church.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: This ſhold be ſome olde buſie turbulent fellowe: villanous Law-worme, that eates holes into poore mēs cauſes.

sp.l: May it pleaſe your worſhip to giue me leaue?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I giue you leaue ſir, you haue your Veniam, now fill me a browne Toſte ſirha.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Will you haue no drink too't ſir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Is that a queſtion in lawe?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.l: Yes, in the loweſt Court: 'ith Sellor ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Let me haa't remou'd preſently ſir.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.l: It ſhall bee done ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now as you were ſaying Sir, ile come to you immediately too.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Oh verie wel ſir:

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I'me a little buſie ſir,
But as how ſir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I pray ſir?
Ha's brought me into the Court, marry my aduerſarie ha's not declarde yet.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non declarauit Aduerſarius ſaiſt thou: what a Villain's that, I haue a tricke to doe thee good: I will get thee out a Proxe, & make him declare with a Poxe to him.

sp.l: That wil make him declare to his fore griefe, I thank your good worſhip: but put caſe he doe declare?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Si declaraſſet, If he ſhould declare there,
I would be loath to ſtād out to the iudgement of that Court

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non ad iudicium, doe you feare corruption? then ile releeue you agaen: you ſhall get a Superſ •… diae, Non moleſt andam; and 〈◊〉 it big her.

sp.l: Verie good.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Now if it ſhould euer come to a Teſtificandum, what be his witneſſes?

sp.l: I little feare his witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Non metuis teſtes? more valiant man then Oreſtes

sp.p: Pleaſe you ſir to diſſolue this into Wine, Ale, or Beere, I come a hundred mile to you I proteſt, and leaue all other counſell behind me.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Nay you ſhal alwayes finde me a ſound Card, I ſtoode not ath Pillorie for nothing in eightie eight, all the world knowes that: now let me diſpatch you ſir; I come to you Preſenter.

sp.l: Faith the partie hath remou'd both bodie and cauſe with a habeas corpus.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Has he that knauerie? But has hee put in baile aboue canſt tell?

sp.l: That I can aſſure your worſhip, he has not.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Why then thy beſt courſe ſhall be, to lay out more money, take out a Procedendo, and bring downe the cauſe and him with a Vengeance.

sp.l: Then he will come indeed

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: As for the other partie, let the Audita querela alone, take me out a ſpecial Supplicauit, which will coſt you inough, and then you pepper him. For the firſt partie after the Procedendo youle get coſts, the cauſe being ſound, youle haue a Iudgement, Nunc pro Tunc, youl get a Venire facies to warne your Iurie, a Decem tales to fill vp the number, and a Capias vt Legatum for your execution.

sp.l: I thanke you my learned counſell.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: What a buſie Caterpiller's this? let's accoſt him in that maner.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Content my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: O my olde admirable fellow, how haue I all this while thirſted to ſalute thee? I knew thee in Octauo of the Duke.—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: In Octauo of the Duke: I remember the yere well.

sp.speaker: Phoe,
sp.l: Bi • h maſſe a luſtie proper man.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Oh was I?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But ſtill in lawe▪

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Still in Law. I had not breath'd elſe now, tis verie marrow, verie manna to me to be in law: ide been dead ere this elſe: I haue found ſuch ſweete pleaſure in the vexation of others, that I could wiſh my yeares ouer and ouer agen, to ſee that fellow a Begger, that bawling Knaue a Gentleman: a matter brough • 'een to a iudgement to day, as far as ere t'was to begin again to morowe: O Raptures I heere a writ of Demur, there a Procedendo, heere a Sui ſurrara, there a Capiendo, Tricks, Delayes▪ Money-lawes:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Is it poſſible olde Lad?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I haue beene a Tearme-trotter my ſelfe anye time this fiue and fortie yeares, a goodly time & a gratious: in which ſpace I ha beene at leaſt ſixteen times beggard, and got vp agen: and in the mire agen, that I haue ſtunke agen, and yet got vp agen.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And ſo cleane and handſome how?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: You ſee it apparantly▪ I cānot hide it frō you: nay more, in foelice hora bee it ſpoken, you ſee i'me olde, yet haue I at this preſent, nine and twentie ſutes in Lawe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Deliuer vs man!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: And all not worth forthy ſhillings.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: May it 〈…〉 cu'd?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: The pleaſure of a man is all.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: An olde fellow and ſuch a ſtinger.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
A ſtake puld out of my hedge, theres one: I was well beaten I remember, that's two: I tooke one a bed with my wife agen her will, that's three: I was cal'd cuckold for my labour▪ that's foure: I tooke another a bed agen, that's fiue thē one cald me wittal that's ſixe: he kild my Dog for Barking, ſea • en: my Maide Seruant was knockt at that time, eight: my wife miſcarryed
with a puſh, Nine, & ſic de coeteris, I haue ſo vext and beggerd the whole pariſh, with proceſſe, Suppoeneas, and ſuch like moleſtations, they are not able to ſpare ſo much readie mony from a Tearme, as woulde ſet vp a new Weather-cocke: the Church-wardens are faine to goe to law with the Poores mony.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: And I ſo fetch vp al the men euery Tearm time that tis impoſſible to be at ciuill cuckoldry, within our ſelues, vnleſſe the whole country riſe vpon our wiues.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A my faith a prettie pollicie.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Nay an excellent ſtratagem: but of all I moſt wonder at the continuall ſubſtance of thy wit, that hauing had ſo many ſuits in law from time to time, thou haſt ſtill mony to relieue 'em.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ha's the beſt fortune for that, I neuer knew him without.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Why doe you ſo much wonder at that? why this is my courſe: my Mare and I come vp ſome fiue dayes before a Tearme.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A good Decorum.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Here I Lodge as you ſee amongſt Innes, and places of moſt receit—

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Verie wittily.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: By which aduantage I diue into Country mens cauſes, furniſh 'em with knauiſh counſell, little to their profite, buzzing into their Eares, this courſe, that writ, this office, that Ʋltimum refugium, as you know I haue words enow for the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Enow a conſcience y faith.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Enow a law, no matter for conſcience. For which buſie and laborious ſweating curteſie, they cannot chuſe but feede me with mony, by which I maintaine mine owne ſuits: ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Why let me hug thee, Caper in mine armes.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p:
Another ſpeciall tricke I haue, no body muſt
know it, which is, to prefer moſt of thoſe men to one Atturney whom I affect beſt, to anſwere which kindneſſe of mine, he will ſweat the better in my cauſe, and doe them the leſſe good, tak't of my worde, I helpt my Atturney to more Clients the laſt Tearme then he will diſpatch all his life time: I did it.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: What a noble memorable deed was there?

sp.speaker: Groo.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Now ſir.

sp.speaker: Groo.
sp.p: There's a kind of captaine, verie robuſtiouſly enquires for you.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: For me? a man of warre: a man of law is fit for a man of warre: we haue no leyſure to ſay prayers: wee both kill a Sunday mornings: Ile not be long from your ſweete companie.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: O no I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What captaine might this be?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou Angell ſent amongſt vs, ſober Law.
Made with meeke Eyes, perſwading Action,
No lowd immodeſt Tongue, voic'd like a virgin,
And as chaſte from ſale,
Saue onely to be heard, but not to raile.
How has abuſe deform'd thee to all Eyes?
That where thy vertues ſat, thy vices riſe,
Yet why ſo raſhly for one villaines fault▪
Doe I arraigne whole man? Admired Law,
Thy vpper parts muſt needes be ſacred, pure,
And incorruptible, th'are graue and wiſe,
T'is but the droſſe beneath 'em, and the clowdes
That get betweene thy glorie and their praiſe,
That make the viſible and foule Eclipſe,
For thoſe that are neere to thee, are vpright,
As noble in their conſcience, as their birth,
Know that damnation is in euery bribe,
And rarely put it from 'em: rate the Preſenters,
And ſcourge 'em with fiue yeares impriſonment,
For off ring but to tempt 'em.
Thus is true iuſtice exerciſde and vſde,
"Woe to the giuer when the Bribe's refuſde.
Tis not their wil, to haue law worſe then warre,
Where ſtill the poor'ſt die firſt,
To ſend a man without a ſheete to his graue,
Or burie him in his Papers.
Tis not their minde it ſhould be, nor to haue
A ſute hang longer then a man in chaines
Let him be nere ſo faſtned, they leaſt know
That are aboue, the tedious ſteps below.
I thanke my time, I doe.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I long to know what captaine this ſhould be:

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: See where the Bane or euery cauſe Returnes.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: S'foote tis the captaine my father in law, my L.

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: Take heede.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: The Diuorſe ſhall reſt then, and the fiue hundred crownes ſhall ſtand in full force and vertue.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Then doe you wiſely Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A way ſayle I, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: A luſtie cracke or winde goe with thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: But ah!

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Hah:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Remember a Scriuener

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Ile haue him for thee. Why thus am I ſought after by all profeſſions; heer's a weather beaten Captaine, who not long ſince newe married to a Ladie widow, would now faine haue ſued a Diuorce betweene her and him, but that her honeſtie is his onely hinderance: to be rid of which, he do's determine to turne her into white mony, and there's a Lord his Chapman has bid fiue hundred Crownes for her alreadie.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Or for his part, or whole in her.

sp.speaker: Phaen.
sp.l: Why, do ſhe •… eaue to ſell his wife?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: His wife? I bith maſſe, he would ſell his ſoule if he knew what Merchant would lay out money vppon't, and ſome of 'em haue need of one they ſweare ſo faſt.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Why, I neuèr heard of the like.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Non audiuiſti, didſtnere heere of that tricke? why Piſtor a Baker ſold his wife tother day to a cheeſemonger, that made Cake and Cheeſe: another to a Coferer: a third to a common player: why you ſee tis cō mon: nere feare the Captaine, be ha's not ſo much witte to bee a praeſident himſelfe: I promiſd to furniſh him with an odde Scriuener of mine owne▪ to draw the bargaine, and ſale of his Lady, your horſes ſtand heere Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I ſhall bee buſilye plung'd till towards bed time, aboue the chin in profundis.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: What monſtrous daies are theſe?
Not onely to be vicious, moſt men ſtudy,
But in it to be vgly, ſtriue to exceed,
Each other in the moſte deformed deede.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Was this her priuate choice? did ſhee neglect
The preſence and opinion of her friends, for this?

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: I wonder who that one ſhould be,
Should ſo diſgrace that Reuerend Name of Lord,
So loathſomly to buy Adulterie?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: We may make meanes to knowe.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.l: Take courage man, weele beget ſome defence.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I am bound by nature.

sp.speaker: Phae.
sp.p: I by Conſcience — To ſell his Lady: indeed ſhe was a Beaſt to marrie him, and ſo he makes of her, come, ile thorowe now 'ime entred.

div.stage: Enter Iewellers wife with a Boy.

sp.p: Is my ſweete Knight comming, are you certaine hee's comming?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Certaine for ſooth, I am ſure I ſaw him out of
the Barbers ſhop, ere I would come away.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: A Barbers ſhop, O hee's a trim Knight, would hee venture his body into a Barbers ſhop, when hee knowes tis as dangerous as a peece of Ireland: O yonder, yonder, hee comes, get you backe agen, and looke you ſay as I aduiz'de you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You know me miſtris?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: My maske, my maske.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: My ſweete Reuenewe!

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: My pleaſure welcome: I haue got ſingle, none but you ſhall accompany mee to the Iuſtice of peace my Fathers.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: Why, is thy Father Iuſtice of Peace, and I not knowe it?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.p: My father! yfaith ſir I, ſimply tho I ſtand heere a Cittizens wife: I am a Iuſtice of Peaces Daughter.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: I loue thee the better for thy birth.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: Hee's at thy ſeruice my ſweete Reuenewe, for thy money paide for e'm.

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.p: Why then let him run a little before I beſeech thee, for a my troth he will diſcouer vs elſe.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: Hee ſhall obey thee, before ſirrha▪ trudge: but doe you meane to lye at your Fathers all night?

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: Why ſhould I deſire your company elſe?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: S'foot where ſhall I lye then.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: What an idle queſtion's that? why doe you hinke I cannot make roome for you in my Fathers houſe, as well as in my huſbands, th'are both good for nothing elſe?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: A man ſo reſolute in valour as a Woman in deſire, were an abſolute Leader.

div.stage: Enter two ſuters with the Iuſtice Falſo.

sp.p: May it pleſe your good worſhip maiſter Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Pleaſe me and pleaſe are your ſelfe,
Thats my word.

sp.p: The partie your worſhip ſent for, will by no means be brought to appeare.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Hee will not, then what would you aduize me to doe therein?
Onely to graunt your worſhips warrant, which is of ſufficient force to compell him.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: No by my faith: you ſhall not haue me in that Trap: am I ſworne Iuſtice of Peace, and ſhall I giue my warrant to fetch a man againſt his will? why there the peace is Broken, wee muſt doe all quietly, if hee come hee's welcome, and as far as I can ſeeyet, hees a foole to bee abſent, I by this golde is hee (which hee gaue me this morning)
Why, but may it pleaſe your good worshippe.—

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I ſay agen pleaſe me and pleaſe your ſelfe, thats my word ſtill.
Sir, the world eſteemes it a Common fauour, vpon the Contempt of the partie, the juſtice to graunt his warrant.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I, tis ſo common, tis the worſe agen, twere the better for me twere otherwiſe.
I proteſt ſir, and this Gentleman can ſay as much, it lyes vpon my halfe vndooing.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I cannot ſee yet, that it ſhould be ſo— I ſee not a croſſe yet.
I beſeech your worſhip ſhowe me your immediate fauour, and accept this ſmall trifle but as a remembrance to my ſucceeding Thankfulnes.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Angels? ile not meddle with them, you giue e'm to my wife not to me.
I, I ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p:
But I pray tell mee nowe, did the partie Ʋina Voce, with his owne mouth deliuer that contempt, that
that he would not appeare, or did you but ieſtint?

sp.l: Ieſt • no a my troth ſir, ſuch was his inſolent anſwer

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: And do you thinke it ſtood with my credite to put vp ſuch an abuſe? will he not appeare ſayes he? Ile make him appeare with a Vengeance Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.p: Do's your worſhip call?

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Draw me a ſtrong limbd warrant for the Gentleman ſpeedily, he will be bountifull to thee: goe and thanke him within.
I ſhall know your worſhip hereafter.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I, I prethee doe. Two Angels one partie, foure another: and I thinke it a great ſparke of wiſdome and policie (if a man come to me for Iuſtice) firſt to knowe his greefes by his fees, which bee light and which bee he •… ie: he may coūterfet els, & make me do Iuſtice for nothing: I like not that▪ for when I meane to be iuſt, let me be paide wel for't: the deed ſo rare, purges the bribe: how now, what's the newes thou art come ſo haſtily? how fares my Knightly Brother?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Troth he nere farde worſe in his life ſir: he nere had leſſe ſtomack to his meate ſince I knew him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why ſir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Indeede hee's dead ſir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Newly deceaſd I can aſſure your Worſhip: the Tabacco-pipe new dropt out of his mouth before I tooke horſe, a ſhrewd ſigne: I knew then there was no way but one with him, the poore pipe was the laſt man he took leaue off in this world, who ſel in three peeces before him, & ſeem'd to mourne inwardly, for it lookt as blacke'th mouth as my maiſter.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Would hee die ſo like a Polititian, & not once write his minde to me?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p:
No Ile ſay that for him ſir: he dyed in the perfect ſtate of memorie, made your worſhip his ful and whole executor: bequeathing his Daughter, and with her all
his wealth, onely to your diſpoſition.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Did he make ſuch a godly end ſaiſt thou? did he die ſo comfortably, and bequeath all to me?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Your neece is at hand ſir, the will, & the witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: What a precious ioy and comfort's this, that a Iuſtices brother can die ſo wel, nay in ſuch a good and happie memorie, to make me full executor. Wel he was too honeſt to liue, and that made him die ſo ſoone: now I beſhrew my heart, I am glad hee's in heauen, has left all his cares and troubles with me, and that great vexation of telling of Money, yet I hope hee had ſo much grace before he died to turn his white mony into gold, a great eaſe to his Executor.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: See here comes your Neece my yong miſtris ſir,

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Ah my ſweete Neece, let me kiſſe thee, & drop a teare betweene thy lips: one teare from an old man is a great matter, the cockes of age are drie, thou haſt loſt a vertuous father, to gaine a notable vncle.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: My hopes now reſt in you next vnder heauē

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Let 'em reſt, let 'em reſt.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Y'are moſt welcome ere ye begin ſir.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: We are both led by oath and dreadfull promiſe,
Made to the dying man at his laſt ſence,
Firſt to deliuer theſe into your hands,
The ſuerties and reuealers of his ſtate.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: With this his onely daughter and your Neece,
Whoſe fortunes are at your diſpoſing ſet,
Vncle and father are in you both met.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Good yfaith, a well ſpoken Gentleman, y'are not an Eſquire ſir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Not ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p:
Not ſir? more's the pitie: by my faith better men then you are, but a great many worſe: you ſee I haue beene a Scholler in my time, tho I'me a Iuſtice nowe: Neece y'are moſt happily welcom, the charge of you is
wholy and ſoly mine owne: and ſince you are ſo fortunately come Neece, Ile reſt a perpetuall widower.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I take the meaning chaſter then the words:
Yet I hope well of both, ſince it is thus,
His phraiſe off ends leaſt that's knowne humourous.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I make my brother (ſaies he) full and whole Executor, honeſtly done of him yfaith, ſeldome can a man get ſuch a brother: and here again ſaies he, very vertuouſly, I bequeath all to him and his diſpoſing: an excellent fellow a my troth, would you might all die no worſe, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: But as much better as might be.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Bleſſe your vprightneſſe maiſter Iuſtice,

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: You'r moſt ſoberly welcome ſir: daughter y'aue that ye kneele for, riſe, ſalute your weeping coozen.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Weeping coozen?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I coozen.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Eye to weeping is verie proper, and ſo is the partie that ſpake it beleeue me, a prettie, fine, ſlender, ſtreight, delicate knit bodie.
sp.l: Oh how it moues a pleaſure through our ſenſes!
How ſmall are womens waſtes to their expences?
I cannot ſee her face, that's vnder water yet.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Newes as cold to the heart as an old mans kindneſſe: my vncle dead?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I haue loſt the deereſt Father.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: If ſhe marry by your conſent, choyce and liking make her dowrie fiue thouſand crowns: hum, fiue thouſand crownes? therefore by my conſent ſhee ſhall nere marry, I will neither chuſe for her, like of it, nor conſent too't.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Now by the pleaſure of my blood a pretty coozen: I would not care, if I were as nere kin to her, as I haue beene to her kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Daughter, what Gentleman might this be?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: No Gentleman ſir, hee's a Knight.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Is he but a knight? troth, I would a ſworne had beene a Gentleman, to ſee, to ſee, to ſee.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Hee's my husbands owne brother, I can tel you (ſir:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thy husbands brother: ſpeak certainly prethee.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I can aſſure you father, my husband and hee has laine both in one bellie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ile ſwear then he is his brother indeed, & by the ſurer ſide: I craue heartie pardon ſweete kinſman that thou haſt ſtood ſo long vnſaluted in the way of kinred.
sp.l: Welcome to my boord: I haue a bed for thee,
My daughters husbands brother ſhall commaund,
sp.p: Keyes of my Cheſts and Chambers.— I haue ſtable for thy horſe, chamber for thy ſelfe, and a loft abou for thy lowzie lackie, all fit, away with handkirchers, drie vp eies, at funeral we muſt cry: now let's be wiſe.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I told you his affection.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It fals ſweetly.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: But here I bar you from all plots to night,
The time is yet too heauie to be light.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Why, I'me còntent, ile ſleepe as chaſt as you,
And wager night by night who keepes moſt true.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Well we ſhall ſee your temper.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Feare not me Fidelio: become you that inuiſible Rope-maker the Scriuener, that binds a mā as he walks yet all his ioynts at libertie, aſwell as ile fit that common folly of Gentry, the eaſie-affecting venturer, and no doubt our purpoſe will arriue moſt happily.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Chaſt dutie my Lord works powerfully in mee, and rather then the poore Ladie my mother ſhould fall vpon the common ſide of rumour to begger her name, I would not only vndergoe all habits, offices, diſguiz'd profeſſions, tho ee'n oppoſite to the temper my blood holds: but in the ſtainleſſe quarrell of her reputation, alter my ſhape for euer.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p:
I loue thee wealthier, thou haſt a noble touch, & by this means which is the only ſafe means to preſerve
thy mother from ſuch an vgly land and ſea monſter as a counterfeit Captain is, he reſigning and baſely ſelling all his eſtate, title, right, and intereſt in his Ladie, as the forme of the writing ſhall teſtifie.
sp.l: What otherwiſe can follow but to haue,
A Ladie ſafe deliuered of a knaue?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I am in debt my life, to the free goodnes of your inuentions.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Oh they muſt euer ſtriue to be ſo good,
"Who ſels his vow is ſtampt the ſlaue of blood.

div.stage: Enter Captaine his Ladie following him.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Ladi.
sp.l: Captaine, my husband.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hence, we're at a price for thee, at a price, wants but the telling, and the ſealing, then —

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: Haue you no ſence, neither of my good name or your owne credit?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Credit? pox of credit, that makes me owe ſo much: it had bine better for me by a thouſand Royals I had loſt my credite, ſeauen yeare ago, t'as vndone me, that's it that makes me flie: what neede I to ſea elſe, in the Spring time, when Woods haue leaues, to looke vpon balde Oake.
sp.l: Happier that man ſay I, whom no man truſts,
It makes him valiant, dares outface the priſons,
Vpon whoſe carkaſſe no Gownde Rauen iets,
Oh he that has no credite owes no debts.
Tis time I were rid on't.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p: Oh why do you ſo wilfully cherriſh your own poyſon? and breath againſt the beſt of life, chaſt credit.
sp.l: Well may I call it chaſt, for like a Maide
Once falſly broke it euer liues decaide.
O Captaine, husband, you name that Diſhoneſt,
By whoſe good power all that are honeſt liue,
What madneſſe is it to ſpeake ill of that,
Which makes all men ſpeake well, take away credite
By which men amongſt men, are well reputed,
That man may liue, but ſtill liues executed.
Oh then ſhewe pittie to that noble Title
Which elſe you doe Vſurpe: you'r no true Captaine,
To let your enemies leade you, foule diſdaine,
And euerlaſting Scandall, Oh beleeue it!
The money you receive for my good name
Will not be halfe enough to pay your ſhame.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: No, ile ſell thee then to the Smocke: ſee heere comes my honourable Chapman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Oh my poyſon!
Him, whome mine honour and mine eye abhors.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Lady, what ſo vniouially departed?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Fine ſhee pollicie? ſhe makes my backe her Bolſter, but before my face, ſhe not indures him, Tricks.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Captaine, how haps it ſhe remou'd ſo ſtrangely?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Oh for Modeſties cauſe awhile my Lord: ſhee muſt reſtraine her ſelfe, ſhee's not yours yet:
sp.l: Beſide, it weare not wiſdome to appeare,
sp.p: Eaſie before my ſight, fah, wherefore ſerues modeſtie but to pleaſure a Lady now and then, and help her from ſuſſpect, that's the beſt vſe tis put too.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Well obſeru'd of a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: No doubt youle be ſoone friendes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I thinke no leſſe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: And make what haſt I can to my ſhip, I durſt wager you'l be vnder ſaile before me.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A pleaſant voyage Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I, a verie pleaſant voyage as can be: I ſee the houre is Ripe, heere comes the Priſons Bawde the bond-maker, one that bindes heires before they are begot.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: And here are the Crownes Captaine, goe? attend,
Let our bay Courſer waite.

div.stage: Enter Phoenix and Fidelio both diſguized.

sp.speaker: Lackey.
sp.l: It ſhall be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A Farmers ſonne, iſt true?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Has crownes to ſcatter?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I giue you your ſalute ſir.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I take it not vnthankfully ſir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I heare a good report of you ſir—y'aue money.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I haue ſo, true.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: An excellent vertue.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I, to keeep from you—heare you me Captaine?
sp.p: I haue a certaine generous itch ſir, to looſe a fewe Angels in the way of profit: tis but a game at Tennis,
sp.l: Where if the ſhip keepe aboue line, tis three to one:
If not, there's but three hundred Angels gone.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Is your venture three hundred? y'are verie pretiouſly welcome: heere's a voyage towarde will make vs all.—

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Beggerly fooles, and ſwarming knaues.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Captaine, whats he?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Feare him not my Lord, hee's a Gull', hee ventures with me, ſome filthy Farmers ſonne, the father's a Iew, and the ſonne a Gentleman:pha.—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Yet he ſhould be a Iew too, for he is new come from giuing ouer ſwine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why, that in our Countrey makes him a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Goe to, tell your money Captaine.

sp.speaker: Capi
sp.l: Read aloft Scriuener. 1.2.—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: To all good and honeſt Chriſtian people, to whō this preſent writing ſhal come: know you for a certain, that I Captaine, for and in the conſideration of the ſum of fiue hundred crownes, haue clearly bargained, ſolde, giuen, graunted, aſſigned and ſet ouer, and by theſe preſents doe cleerly bargaine, ſell, giue, graunt, aſſigne and ſet ouer, al the right, eſtate, title, intereſt, demaund, poſſeſſion, and tearme of yeares to come, which I the ſaide Captaine haue, or ought to haue.—

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: If I were as good as I ſhould be,—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p:
In and to Madona Caſtiza, my moſt vertuous,
modeſt, louing, and obedient wife.—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: By my troth my Lord and ſo ſhe is.— 3.4.5.6.7.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The more Slaue he that ſayes it, and not ſees it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Togither, with all and ſingular thoſe admirable qualities with which her noble breſt is furniſht.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Well ſaid Scriuener, haſt put'em all in: you ſhal heare now my L.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: In primis, the beuties of her minde, chaſtitie, temperance, and aboue all, pacience:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You haue bought a Iewell yfaith, my L, nine and thirtie, fortie.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Excellent in the beſt of Muſicke, in voice delicious: in conference wiſe and pleaſing: of age contentful: neither too yōg to be a piſh, nor too old to be ſottiſh

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: You haue bought as louely a penny-woorth my Lord, as ere you bought in your life.

sp.speaker: Pro
sp.l: Why ſhould I buy her elſe Captaine?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And which is the beſt, of a wife a moſt comfortable ſweete companion.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I could not affoord her ſo y faith, but that I am-going to ſea and haue need of money.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A moſt comfortable ſweete companion.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: What agen? the Scriuener reades in paſſion.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I read as the words moue me: yet if that be a faul it ſhall be ſeen no more,—which ſaid Madona Casti •• a lying, & yet being in the occupatiō of the ſaid captain

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ninteene—occupation? Pox out, out with occupation, a Captaine is of no occupation, man.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Nor thou of no religion.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Now I come to the Habendum, to haue and to holde, vſe and—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Vſe? put out vſe too for ſhame.
Till we are all gone, I prethee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And to be acquited of and from all former bargaines, former ſales:

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
Former ſailes, nine & twenty thirty, by my troth
my Lord, this is the firſt time that euer I ſolde her.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Yet the writing muſt run ſo Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Let it run on then, nine and fortie, fiftie, —

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Former ſales, Guiftes, Grants, Surrenders. Reentryes. —

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: For Reentryes, I will not ſweare for her.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And furdermore (I the ſaid) of and for the conſideration of the ſomme of fiue hundred Crownes to ſet me a boord before theſe preſents vtterly diſclaime for euer, any Title, eſtate, right, intereſt, demaund, or poſſeſſion, in or to the ſaid Madona Caſtiza, my late vertuous, and vnfortunate wife.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Vnfortunate indeede, that was wel plac'd.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: As alſo neither to touch, attempt, moleſt, or incumber any parte, or partes whatſoeuer: either to bee namde or not to be namde: eyther hidden or vnhidden, eyther thoſe that boldly looke abroad, or thoſe that dare not ſhow their face.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Faces: I knowe what you meane by faces: Scriuener, there's a great figure in faces.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: In witneſſe wherof, I the ſaid Captaine haue interchangeably ſet to my hand and ſeale: in preſence of all theſe, the day and date aboue written.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Verie good ſir, Ile bee ready for you preſently, foure hundred and twentie. 1.2.3.4.5.—

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Of all deedes, yet this ſtrikes the deepeſt wound
Into my apprehenſion,
Reuerend, and honourable Matrimony,
Mother of lawfull ſweetes, vnſhamed mornings:
Dangerleſſe pleaſures, thou that mak'ſt the bed,
Both pleaſant, and legitimately fruitfull: without thee,
All the whole world were ſoyled Baſtardy.
Thou art the onely and the greateſt forme.
That put'ſt a difference betweene our deſires
And the diſordered appetites of Beaſtes,
Making their mates, thoſe that ſtand next their luſts.
Then,—with what baſe iniurie is thy goodnes paide
Firſt, rare to haue a Bride commence a Maide,
But do's beguile ioy of the puritie:
And is made ſtrickt by power of Drugs and Art,
An Artificall Maide, a Doctord Virgin,
And ſo deiceues the glorie of his bod:
A foule contempt, againſt the ſpotleſſe power
Of ſacred wedlocke, but if chaſt and honeſt,
There is another Deuill hauntes marriage,
(None fondly loues but knowes it) Iealouſie,
That Wedlocks yellow ſicknes, that whiſpering ſeperation euerie minute.
And thus the curſſe takes his effect or progreſſe,
The moſte of men in their firſt ſuddaine furyes,
Rayle at the narrow boundes of marriage,
And cal't a priſon then it is moſte iuſt,
That the diſeaſe'ath priſon, Ielouſie
Should ſtill affect a'm, but oh! here I am fixt,
To make ſale of a wife, monſtrous and foule,
An act abhord in nature, could in ſoule:
Who that ha's man in him, could ſo reſigne,
To make his ſhame, the poeſye to the Coyne?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Right yfaith, my Lord fully fiue hundred,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: I ſaide how you ſhould finde it Captaine, and with this competent ſumme you reſt amplye contented.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Amply contented.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Heere's the Pen Captaine: your name to the ſale.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: S'foote dooſt take me to be a pen-man? I proteſt I could nere write more then A, B, C, thoſe three letters in my life.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: Why thoſe will ſerue Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I could nere get furder.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Would you haue got furder then A B C? ah Baſe Captaine, that's far ynough yfaith.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Take the Seale off Captaine.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It goes on hardly, and comes off eaſily.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I iuſt like a Coward.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Will you write witneſſe Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Hee? he ſhall, prethe come and ſet thy hand for witneſſe Rogue, thou ſhall venture with me?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Nay, then I ha reaſon Captaine that commaunds me?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What a faire fiſt the pretty whorſone writes, as if he had had manners and bringing vp, a farmers Sonne: his Father dam's himſelfe to ſell muſtie Corne, while hee ventures the Money, twill proſper well at Sea no doubt he ſhall nere ſee't agein

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: So, Captaine you deliuer this as your deede.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: As my deede, what elſe ſir?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The ouglyeſt deed that ere mine eye did witnes

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: So my Lord, you haue her, clip her, enioy her, ſhee's your owne, and let me be proud to tell you now my Lord, ſhee's as good a ſoule if a man had a minde to liue honeſt, and keepe a wench, the Kindeſt, ſweeteſt, comfortableſt Rogue.—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Harke in thine eare,
The Baſer ſlaue art thou: and ſo ile tell her,
I loue the Pearle, thou ſoldſt, hate thee the Seller—
Goe, to Sea, the end of thee—is Lowſie.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: This fine worke: a verie braue end, hum—

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Wel thought vpon, this Scriuener may furniſh me

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why ſhould this fellowe be a Lord by birth?
Being by bloud a Knaue, one that would ſell
His Lordſhip if he likt her Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: What's here Now?

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: I haue imployment for a truſtie fellow, bould, ſure—

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What if he be a Knaue my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p:
There thou comſt to me, why he ſhould be ſo,
and men of your quill are not vnacquainted.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Indeed al our chiefe liuing my Lord, is by fooles and knaues, we could not keepe open ſhop elſe▪ Fooles that enter into bonds, and Knaues that binde e'm.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Why now we meete.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: And as my memorie happily leades me: I know a fellowe of a ſtanding eſtate, neuer flowing: I durſt conuey treaſon into his boſome,
sp.l: And keepe it ſafe nine yeares.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A goodly Time.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: And if neede were would preſſe to an attempt,
And cleaue to Deſperate action.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: That Laſt fits mee.
Thou haſt the meaſure right, looke I heare from thee.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: With duteous ſpeede.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Expect a large reward:
I will finde time of her to finde regard.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The end of me is lowzie.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Oh my Lord! I haue ſtrange wordes to tell you.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Stranger yet? ile chuſe ſome other hower to liſten to thee, I am yet ſicke of this, diſcouer quickly.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why, wil you make yourſelfe knowne my Lord

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I.
Who ſcourgeth ſinne let him doo't dreadfully.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Pox of his diſſemblance: I will to ſ • n.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Nay, you ſhall to ſea, thou wouldſt poyſon the whole land elſe—why how now Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: In health.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: What, drooping?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Or a ſhamde of the ſale of thine owne wife?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You might count me an aſſe then yfaith.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: If not a ſham'd of that, what can you be a ſhamd ofthen?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Prethe ha done, I am aſham'd of nothing.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I eaſily beleeue that.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This Lord ſtickes in my ſtomacke.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How? take one of thy fethers downe, and fetch him vp.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ide make him come.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: But what if the Duke ſhould heare of this?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I, or your Sonne in Law, Fidelio knowes of the ſale of his mother.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: What and they did, I ſell none but mine owne: as for the Duke, hee's abroad by this time, and for Fidelio hee's in labour.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Hee, in labour?

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: What call you Trauelling?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: That's true:— but let me tell you Captain: whether the Duke heare on't, or Fidelio know on't: or both, or neither, twa's a moſte filthie loathſome part.

sp.speaker: Fid
sp.l: A baſe vnnaturall deede—

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: Slaue and foole: —ha, who? oh—

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou hatefull villaine: thou ſhouldſt chuſe (to ſincke
To keepe thy baſenes ſhrouded.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ougly wretch.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.l: Who hath laid violence vpon my husband?
My deare ſweet Captaine, helpe—

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Lady you wrong your value,
Call you him deere that has ſolde you ſo cheape?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I do beſeech your pardon good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Riſe.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My abuſed Mother:

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My kinde Sonne,
Whoſe liking I neglected in this match.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Not that alone, but you far happyer fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cap
sp.l: Is this the Scriuener and the Farmers Sonne,
Fire on his Lordſhip he tolde me they Trauaild.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And ſee the ſumme tolde out to buy that Iewel
More pretious in a Woman then her eye, her honour:
Nay take it to you Lady, and liudge it,
sp.p:
Too ſlight a recōpence, for your great wrong, but that
his riddance helpes it.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.l: S'foot he vndoes me, I am a Rogue & a Beggar,
The Aegiptian plague creepes ouer me alreadie,
I begin to be lowſie.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Thus happily preuented, y'are ſet free,
Or elſe made ouer to adulterie.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: To heauen and to you my modeſt thankes.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Monſter, to ſea, ſpit thy al herred foame,
Where it may doe leaſt harme, ther's ayre and roeme.
Thour't Dangerous in a Chamber, Ʋirulext Ʋenem,
Vnto a Ladies name, and her chaſt breath
If paſt this euenings verge, the Dukedome hold thee,
Thou art reſeru'd for abiect puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Cap:
sp.p: I doe beſeech your good Lordſhip conſider the ſtate of a poore downe-caſt Captaine.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Captaine, off with that noble title thou becomſt it vildely, I nere ſaw the name fit worſe, ile ſooner allowe a Pandar a Captaine then thee.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: More's the pittie.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sue to thy Lady for pardon.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: I giue it without ſuite.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: I do beſeech your Ladiſhip not ſo much for pardon, as to beſtow a few of thoſe Crownes vpon a poore vnfethered Rouer that will as truely pray for you, and wiſh you hangd, as any man breathing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I giue it freely all.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Nay by your fauour:
I will containe you Lady, here▪ be gone:
Vſe ſlaues like ſlaues—wealth keepes their faults vnkowne.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Well 'ime yet glad, i'ue libertie and theſe:
The Land has plagu'd me, and ile plague the ſeas.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The Sceane is cleer'd, the bane of brightnes fled
Who ſought the death of honour, is ſtrucke dead.
Come modeſt Lady:

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: My moſte honeſt mother.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thy vertue ſhall liue ſafe from reach of ſhames,
That Act endes nobly, preſerues Ladies fames.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Why this is but the ſecond time of your comming Kinſman, viſit me oftner, Daughter, I charge you bring this Gentleman along with you: Gentleman, I I crie yee mercy ſir, I call you Gentleman ſtill: I forget y'are but a Knight, you muſt pardon me ſir.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.p: For your worſhips kindenes—worſhip I crie you mercie ſir, I call you worſhipfull ſtill, I forget, y'are but a Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I am no more yfaith.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: You muſt pardon me ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Tis quickly done ſir, you ſee I make bould with you Kinſman, thruſt my Daughter and you into one Chamber.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Beſt of all ſir: Kinred you knowe may lye anye where.

sp.speaker: Falſ
sp.p: True, true ſir, Daughter receiue your bleſſing— take heed the Coach iopper not to much▪ haue a care to the fruits of your bodye—looke to her Kinſman.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Feare it not ſir.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: Nay Father though I ſay it, that ſhould not ſay it, hee lookes to me more like a husband then a Kinſman.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I heare good commendations of you ſir.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: You heare the worſt of me I hope ſir,—I ſalute my leaue ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Y'are welcome all ouer your body ſir: nay, I can behaue my ſelfe courtly, though I keepe houſe 'ith Countrie: what, does my Neece hide herſelfe, not preſent, ha? Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Call my Neece to mee.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p:
A fooliſh, coy, baſhfull thing it is, ſhee's afraid
to lie with her owne Vncle: ide do her no harme yfaith, I keepe my ſelfe a widdower a purpoſe, yet the fooliſh Girle will not looke into't, ſhee ſhould haue all yfaith, ſhee knowes I haue but a time, cannot holde long, ſee where ſhe comes, pray whome am I Neece?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I hope y'are your ſelfe.
Vncle to me, and Brother to my Father.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Oh am I ſo, it do's not appeare ſo,—for ſurely you would loue your Fathers Brother for your Fathers ſake, your Vncle for your owne ſake.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I doe ſo.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Nay you doe nothing Neece.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: In that loue which becomes you beſt I loue (you.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: How ſhould I know that loue becomes me beſt?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Becauſe tis chaſt, and honorable.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Honorable! it cannot become me then Neece.
For'ime ſcarce worſhipfull: Is this an age,
To entertaine bare loue without the fruites
When I receiu'd thee firſt, I look't
Thou ſhouldſt haue beene a wife vnto my houſe
And ſau'd me from the charge of marriage.
sp.p: Do you thinke your Fathers fiue thouſand pound wold ha made me take you elſe? no, you ſhould neere a ha beene a charge to me.
sp.l: As far as I can perceiue yet by you,
sp.p: I'ue as much neede to marrie as ere I had: would not this be a greate griefe to your friendes thinke you, if they were aliue agen?

sp.speaker: Neece:
sp.l: Twould be a griefe indeede.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Y'aue confeſt
All about houſe, that young Fidelio
Who in his Trauailes does attend the Prince,
Is your vowde loue.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Moſt true, hee's my vow'd Husband.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p:
And what's a Husband is not a Husband a ſtrāger at firſt, and wil you lye with a ſtranger before
you lie with your owne Vncle? take heede what yee doe Neece, I counſell you for the beſt: ſtrangers are drunken fellowes I can tell you, they will come home late a nights, beate their wiues, and get nothing but Girles: look too't, if you marry, your ſtubbernes is your Dowrie: fiue thouſand Crownes were bequeathed to you, true, if you marry with my conſent: but if ere you goe to marrying by my conſent, ile goe to hanging by your's: goe too▪ be wiſe and loue your Vncle.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I ſhould haue cauſe then to repent indeede.
Do you ſo far forget the Offices
Of bluſhing modeſtie? Vncles are halfe Fathers,
Why they come ſo neare our bloods th'are ene part of it.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Why now you come to mee Neece: if your Vncle be part of your owne fleſh and blood, is it not then fit your owne fleſh and bloud ſhould come neereſt to you? anſwere me to that Neece.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: You doe allude all to inceſtuous will,
Nothing to modeſt purpoſe: turne me foorth,
Be like an Vncle of theſe latter daies,
Periurde ynough, ynough vnnaturall,
Play your Executorſhip, in Tyranny,
Reſtraine my fortunes, keepe me poore, I care not,
In this alone moſte women ile excell,
Ile rather yelde to beggery then to hell.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Very good, a my troth my Neece is Valiant, ſha's made me ritcher by fiue thouſand Crownes, the price of her Dowrie: are you ſo honeſt, I doe not feare but I ſhall haue the Conſcience to keepe you poore ynough Neece, or elſe I am quite altered a late—The Newes, may it pleaſe you ſir?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.p: Sir, theres an olde fellowe, a kinde of Law-driuer, entreates conference with your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: A Law-driuer, prethee driue him hither.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: No, no I ſay if it bee for defect of Apparance, take me out a ſpeciall Significauit.

sp.speaker: Whin.
sp.l: Verie good ſir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Then if he purchaſe an Alias or Capias, which are Writs of cuſtome, onely to delay time, your Procedendo do's you Knights ſeruice—that's nothing at all, get your Diſtringas out as ſoone as you can for a Iurie.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ile attend your god worſhips comming out.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Do I prethee, attend me, ile take it kindly, a Voluntate.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: What, old Seigneur Tangle!

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I am in debt to your worſhips remembrance.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: My old maſter of Fence: come, come, come, I haue not exerciz'd this twelue Moones, I haue almoſt forgot all my Law-weapons.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: They are vnder fine and Recouerie, your worſhip ſhall eaſily recouer them.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I hope ſo: when there?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: The Rapler and Dagger foyles inſtantly: and whats thy ſuite to mee olde Tangle, ile graunt it preſently.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nothing but this ſir, to ſet your worſhips hand to the commendation of a Knaue whome no bodye ſpeakes well on.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: The more ſhame for e'm, what was his offence I pray?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Veſtras Deducite Culpas—nothing but robbing a Veſtrie.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p:
What, what! alaſſe poore Knaue, giue me the Paper, he did but ſaue the Churchwardens a labour: come, come, he has done a better deed in't then the pariſh is a aware off, to preuent the Knaues, hee robs but ſeldome, they once a quarter: me thinks twere a part of good iuſtice, to hang e'm at yeares end, wen they come out of
their office, to the true terrifying of all Collectors and Sidemen.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your worſhip would make a fruitefull Common-wealths man, the Conſtable lets e'm alone, looks on, and ſayes nothing.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: A laſſe good man, he lets e'm alone for quietnes ſake, and takes halfe a ſhare with e'm: they know wel enough too, he ha's an impediment in his tongue, hee's alwaies drunke when he ſhould ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Indeede your worſhip ſpeakes true in that ſir: they blinde him with beere, and make him ſo narrowe eyde, that he wincks naturallye at all their Knaueries,

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: So, ſo, heeres my hand to his commendations.

sp.speaker: Tangle.
sp.l: A Charitate, you doe a charitable deede in't ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Nay, if it be but a Veſtrie matter, viſit me at anye time, olde Signeor Law-thiſtle! O well done, heere are the Foiles, come, come ſir, ile trie a Law-bout with you.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: I am affraide I ſhall ouerthrowe you ſir yfaith.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Tis but for want of vſe then ſir.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Indeed that ſame odde word Vſe, makes a man a good Lawyer, and a woman an arrant—tuh tuh, tuh, tuh, tuh, now am I for you ſir: but firſt to bring you into forme, can your worſhip name all your weapons?

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: That I can I hope, let me ſee, Longſwoord, what's Longſword? I am ſo duld with dooing juſtice, that I haue forgot all yfaith.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Your long ſword, thats a writ of delay.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Maſſe that ſwords long enough indeede, I ha knowne it reach the length of fifteene Tearmes.

sp.speaker: Tang
sp.l: Fifteene Tearmes, that's but a ſhort ſword.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Me thinkes tis long enough, proceede ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: A Writ of Delay, Long-ſword.
Scandala Magnatum, Backeſword.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Scandals are back-ſwords indeede

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Capias cominus, Caſe of Rapyers.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Oh Deſperate!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: A Latitat, ſword and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: A writ of Execution, Rapier and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Thou art come to our preſent weapon, but what call you ſword and Buckler then?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh! that's out of vſe now, ſword and Buckler was cal'd a good conſcience, but that weapons left long agoe, that was too manly a fight, too ſound a weapon for theſe our daies, ſl'id wee are ſcarce able to lift vp a Buckler now, our armes are ſo bound to the Poxe: one good bang vppon a Buckler would make moſte of our Gentlemen flye a peeces, tis not for theſe lintie times, our Lawyers are good Rapyer and Dagger men, theile quickly diſpatch your—money.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Indeede ſince ſword and buckler time, I haue obſeru'd, there ha's beene nothing ſo much fighting: where bee all our gallant Swaggerers? there are no good frayes alate.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh ſir, the properties altred, you ſhall ſee leſſe fighting euerie day then other, for euerie one gets him a Miſtris, and ſhe giues him woundes enowe, and you knowe, the Surgeons cannot beehere and there too, if there were red woundes too, what wold become of the Reiniſh woundes?

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Thou ſaiſt true yfaith, they would bee but il favouredly lookt to then.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Verie well ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I expect you ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I lye in this court for you ſir, my Rapyer is my Atturney, and my Dagger his Clarke.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Your Atturney wants a little oyling, me thinkes, he lookes very Ruſtily.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tis but his proper colour ſir, his Father was an Iremonger, he will nere look brighter, the ruſt ha's ſo eat into him, ha's neuer any leaſure to be made cleane.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Not in the vacation.

l.hi: Non Vacat exiguis rebus adeſſe Ioui.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Then Ioue will not be at leyſure to ſcoure him, becauſe he • ere came to him before.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Y'are excellent at it ſir—and now you leaſt thinke on't, I arreſt you ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Very good ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay very bad ſir by my faith—I followe you ſtill, as the Officers wil followe you as long as you haue a penny.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: You ſpeake ſentences ſir—by this time haue I tryed my friendes, and now I thruſt in baile—

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.p: This baile will not be taken ſir, they muſt be two Cittizens that are no Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Berlady then 'ime like to lye by it, I had rather twere a hundred that were.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Take heede I bring you not to an Niſiprius ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I muſt ward my ſelfe as well as I may ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Tis Court day now, Declarat Atturnatus, my Atturney gapes for money.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: You ſhall haue no Aduantage yet, I put in my Anſwere.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I follow the ſute ſtill ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I like not this Court birlady—I: take me out a writ of Remoue, a writ of Remoue, doe you ſee ſir?

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.l: Very well ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: And place my cauſe higher.

sp.speaker: Tang,
sp.p: There you ſtarted me ſir—yet for all your Demurres, Plures, and Surſurarers, which are all Longſwords: that's Delaies: al the comfort is, in nine yeares a man may ouerthrowe you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You muſt thanke your good friendes then ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p:
Let nine yeares paſſe, fiue hundred crownes caſt away a both ſides, and the ſuite not twentie, my Counſellors wife muſt haue another hood you knowe, and my Atturneyes wife wil haue a new forepart, yet
ſee at length law, I ſhal haue law: now beware, I bring you to a narrowe exigent, and by no meanes can you auoide the Proclamation—

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now followes a writ of execution, a Capias, vt Legatum, giues you a wound mortall, trippes vp your heeles, and layes you ith Counter.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: O Villaine!

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: I crie your worſhip heartily mercie ſir, I thought we had beene in Lawe together, Aduerſarius contra aduerſarium by my troth.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Oh! reach me thy hand, I nere had ſuch an ouerthrowe in my life.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Twa's long of your Atturney there, hee might a ſtaide the execution of Capias vt Legatum, and remou'd you with a Superſedeas non moleſtandum into the Court of Equitie.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Pox on him, he fell out of my hand when I had moſt neede of him,

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I was bound to follow the ſuite ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Thou couldſt doe no leſſe then ouerthrowe me,
I muſt needes ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: You had recouered coſt elſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: And now by'th maſſe I thinke I ſhal hardly recouer without coſt.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay, that's Certoſcio, an execution is very chargeable.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Well, it ſhall teach mee witte as long as I am a Iuſtice: I perceiue by this tryall, if a man haue a ſound fall in Law, hee ſhall feele it in his bones all his life after.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Nay, that's Recto vpon Record, for I my ſelfe was ouerthrowne in eighty eight by a Taylor, and I haue had a Stitch in my ſide euer ſince, oh!

div.stage: Toward the cloſe of the muſick, the Iuſtices three men prepare for a robberie.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Why Latronello, Furtiuo, Fucato, where be theſe lazie knaues that ſhould truſſe me, not one ſtirring yet?

sp.speaker: A crie within.
sp.p: Followe, followe, followe.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: What newes there?

sp.speaker: A cry.
sp.l: This way, this way, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Hark you ſluggiſh Soporiferous villaines, ther's knaues abroad when you are a bed, are ye not a ſham'd on't, a Iuſtices men ſhould be vp firſt, and giue example all knaues.

div.stage: Enter two of his men tumbling in, in Falſe beards.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: Oh I beſeech your good worſhip.

sp.speaker: Fuca.
sp.l: Your worſhipfull worſhip.

sp.speaker: Fal.
