sp.p: Theeues, my two hand ſword, ime rob'd 'ith Hal, Latronello, Knaues, come down, my two hand ſword I

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: I am Latronello, I beſeech your worſhip, (ſay.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Thou Latronello, thou lyeſt, my men ſcorne to haue beardes.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.p: We forget our beards, now I beſeech your worſhip quickly remember vs.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Fuc.
sp.l: Nay theres no time to talke of how now, tis don.

sp.speaker: A cry.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.p: Foure marke and a Liuerie is not able to keepe life and ſoule together, wee muſt flye out once a quarte, tis for your worſhips credit to haue moneye in our purſſe, our Fellow Furtiuo is taken in the Action.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: A pox on him for a lazie knaue, would hee bee taken?

sp.speaker: Fuc.
sp.p: They bring him along to your worſhip, your the next Iuſtice, now or neuer ſhow your ſelfe a good maiſter, an vpright Magiſtrate, and deliuer him out of their hands.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Nay, he ſhal finde me—apt enough to doe him good I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Latr:
sp.l: Hee comes in a falſe beard ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: S'foot what, ſhould hee doe here elſe? there's no comming to me in a true on: if he had one,—the ſlaue to be taken: doe not I keepe Geldings ſwift enough?

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.p: The goodlyeſt Geldings of any Gentleman in the ſhire.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Which did the whorſon knaue ride vpon?

sp.speaker: Enter.
sp.l: Vpon one of your beſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Fucat.
sp.l: Stand and deliuer.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Vpon Stand and Deliuer: the verie Gelding I chuſe for mine owne riding, as nimble as Pegaſus the flying horſe yonder: goe ſhift your ſelues into your coates, bring hither a great chaire, and a little table.

sp.speaker: Fucat.
sp.l: With all preſent ſpeede ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: And Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: I ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Sit you downe, & very ſoberly take the examnation.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.p: Ile drawe a few horſe heades in a paper, make a ſhew: I hope I ſhall keepe my countenence.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Pox on him agen, would he be taken? hee frets me: I haue beene a youth my ſelfe, I ha ſeene the day I could haue told money out of other mens purſes (Maſſe ſo I can doe now) nor will I keepe that fellow about me that dares not bid a man ſtand: for as long as drunkenneſſe is a vice, ſtand is a vertue: but I would not haue 'em taken. I remember now betimes in a morning I would haue peept through the greene boughs, & haue had the partie preſently, and then to ride away ſinelye in feare, twas e'en Venerie to me yfaith, the pleaſantſt courſe of life, one would thinke euery Woodcok a Conſtable, and euery Owle an officer, but thoſe dayes are paſt with mee: and a my troth I thinke I am a greater theefe now, and in no danger: I can take my eaſe, ſit in my Chaire, look in your faces now, and rob you, make you bring your money by authoritie put off your hat, and thanke me for robbing of you, O there is nothing to a theefe vnder Couert Barne.

stage.hi: Enter Phoenix, Fidelio being robd, Conſtable, Officers and the Theefe Furtino.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Come Officers bring him away.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Nay, I ſee thee through thy falſe beard, thou mid-winde chinde Raſcall,
sp.l: How now my Maiſters, whats he? ha?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Your worſhip knowes, I neuer come but I bring a theefe with me.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Thou haſt left thy wont elſe Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Sir, we vnderſtand you to be the onely vp rightnes of this place.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: But I ſcare vnderſtand you ſir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why then you vnderſtand not your ſelfe ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Such another word, and you ſhal change places with the Theefe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A maintayner of equall cauſes I meane.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Now I haue you, proceede ſir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: This Gentleman and my ſelfe, being led heather by occaſion of buſineſſe, haue beene offered the diſcurteſie of the Country, ſet vppon by three theeues and rob'd.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: What are become of the other two, Latronello, and Fuca?

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: Heere ſir.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: They both made away from vs, the crie purſues e'm, but as yet none but this taken.

sp.speaker: Latron.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Take his examination.

sp.speaker: Latro.
sp.l: Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Let the Knaue ſtand ſingle.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Thanke your good worſhip.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Ha's beene a ſuter at Court ſure, hee thankes me for nothing.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Hee's a Theefe now ſure.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: That we muſt know of him, what are you ſir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: A peece next to the Taile ſir—a Seruingman.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p:
By my troth a prettie phraſe and verye
cleanly handled, put it downe Latronello: thou mayſt make vſe on't. Is hee of honour or worſhip whom thou ſerueſt?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Of both deere ſir, honourable in minde, and worſhipfull in bodie.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Why would one wiſh a man to ſpeake better?

sp.speaker: Phoen
sp.l: Oh ſir, they moſt commonly ſpeake beſt, that doe worſt.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Say you ſo ſir, then weele trie him farther, — Do's your right worſhipfull maiſter, goe before you, as an enſample of Vice, and ſo encourage you to this ſlinking iniquitie? hee is not a Lawer, is he?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Ha's the more wrong ſir, both for his conſcience, and honeſtie, he deſerues to be one.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Pittie hee's theefe yfaith, I ſhould entertaine him elſe.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: I, if he were not as he is, hee would be better then himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: No tis well knowne ſir, I haue a maiſter, the verie picture of wiſdome,

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: For indeed he ſpeakes not one wiſe worde.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And no man but will admire to heare of his Vertues.

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: Becauſe he nere had any in all his life.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: You write all downe Latronello.

sp.speaker: Latr.
sp.l: I warrant you ſir.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: So ſober, ſo diſcrete, ſo iudicious:

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And aboue all, of moſt reuerend grauitie.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: I like him for one qualitie, hee ſpeakes well of his maiſter, he will fare the better:—Now ſir, let mee touch you,

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: I ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p:
Why, ſeruing a Gentleman of ſuch worſhip and wiſdome, ſuch ſobrietie and vertue, ſuch diſcretion and iudgement as your maſter is, doe you take ſuch a beaſtly
courſe, to ſtop horſes, hinder Gentlewomen from their meetings, and make Citizens neuer ride but a Sundaies, onely to auoyd Morning praier and you: is it becauſe your worſhipfull Ma. feeds you with leane ſpits, paies you with Iriſh mony, or clothes you in northern dozēs?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: Farre be it from his mind, or my report, Tis well knowne he kept worſhipful cheer the day of his wiues burial, payes our foure marks a yeare as duly by twelue pence a quarter as can be.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: His wiſdome ſwallowes it.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: And for Northren dozens, fie, fie, wee were nere troubled with ſo many.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Receiuing then ſuch plenteous bleſſings from your vertuous and bountiful maſter, what cauſe haue you to be theefe now? anſwer me to that geere:

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Tis ee'n as a man giues his mind too't ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: For alas, if the whole worlde were but of one trade; traffique were nothing: if wee were all truemen, wee ſhould bee of no trade: what a pittifull world would heere bee, heauen forbid we ſhould bee all truemen: then howe ſhould your worſhips next ſuite bee made? not a Tayler left in the lande: of what ſtuffe would you haue it made? not a Merchant left to deliuer it, would your worſhip goe in that ſute ſtill? You would ha more theeues about you then thoſe you haue baniſht, and be glad to call the great ones home agen, to deſtroy the little.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A notable Rogue.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A my troth, a fine knaue, & ha's anſwered me gloriouſly, what wages wilt thou take after thou art hāg'd?

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.p: More then your worſhip's able to giue, I would thinke foule ſcorne to be a Iuſtice then.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: He ſayes true too yfayth, for we are all full of corruption here,—hearke you my friends.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: By my troth if you were no crueller then I, I could find in my hart to let him goe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Could you ſo ſir, the more pittiful Iuſtice you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay I did but to trie you, if you haue no pittie, Ile ha none, away hee's a Theefe, to priſon with him.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: I am content ſir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Are you content, bring him backe, nay then you ſhall not goe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ile be as cruel as you can wiſh: y'are content, belike you haue a tricke to breake priſon, or a bribe for the Officers.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: For vs ſir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: For you ſir? what colour's ſiluer I pray, you nere ſaw mony in your life:—Ile not truſt you with him, Latronello and Fucato, lay hold vpon him, to your charge I commit him.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Oh, I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Nay if I muſt be cruell, I will be cruell.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Good ſir, let me rather goe to priſon.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You deſire that▪—Ile truſt no priſon with you, Ile make you lye in mine own houſe, or Ile know why I ſhal not.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Mercifull ſir.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Since you haue no pittie I will be cruell.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Verie good ſir, you pleaſe vs well.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: You ſhall appeare to morrow ſirs.

sp.speaker: Furt.
sp.l: Vpon my kees ſir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You ſhall be hang'd out a'th way, away with him Latronello, and Fucato,—Officers I diſcharge you my houſe, I like not your companie.
sp.l: Report me as you ſee me, fire and fuell,
If men be Iewes, Iuſtices muſt be cruell.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: So ſir, Extreames ſet of all Actions thus,
Eyther too tame, or elſe too tyranous:
He being bent to furie, I doubt now
We ſhall not gaine acceſſe vnto your loue or ſhe to vs.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Moſt wiſhfully here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Is that ſhee?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: This is ſhe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A modeſt preſence.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Vertue bleſſe you Ladie,

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: You wiſh me well ſir.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I'de firſt in charge this kiſſe, and next this paper,
You'le know the language, tis Fidelios.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: My euer vowed loue, how is his health?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: As faire as is his fauour with the Prince.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: I'me ſick with ioy, do's the Prince loue him ſo?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: His life cannot requite it,
Not to wrong the remembrance of his loue,
I had a token for you, kept it ſafe,
Till by misfortune of the way this morning,
Theeues ſet vpon this Gentleman and my ſelfe,
And with the reſt robd that.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Oh me, I'me deerly ſorie for your chance, was it your loſſe?
They boldly looke you in the face that rob'd you,
No farther villaines then my vncles men.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: What Ladie?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Tis my griefe I ſpeake ſo true.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Why my Lord?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: But giue me pawſing Lady: was hee one that tooke the examination?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: One and the chiefe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Hence-forth hang him that is no way a theefe,
sp.p: Then I hope few will ſuffer,—nay all the ieſt was, hee committed him to the charge of his fellowes, and the rogue made it lamentable, cryed to leaue'em.
sp.l: None liue ſo wiſe but fooles may once deceiue em?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: An vncle ſo inſaciate?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I, Iſt not ſtrange too,
That al ſhould be by Nature vicious, and he bad againſt
Nature?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Then you haue heard the ſum of al my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Lady, we haue, and deſire rather now
To heale 'em, then to heare 'em:
For by a letter from Fidelio
Direct to vs, we are entreated ioyntly,
To haſten your remoue▪ from this foule den,
Of theft and purpos'd inceſt:

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I reioyce in his chaſt care of mee, Ile ſoone bee furniſht.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: He writes that his returne cannot be long.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I'me chiefly glad,—but whither is the place?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: To the ſafe ſeate of his late wronged mother.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I deſire it,—
Her conference will fit mine, well you preuaile,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: At next groue weele expect you:

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Ile not faile.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: It ſtands vpon the frame of my reputation I proteſt Ladie.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: Ladie, that worde is worth an hundred Angels at all times, for it coſt more: if I liue til tomorrow night, my ſweete pleaſure thou ſhalt haue them.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Could you not make 'em a hundred and fiftie thinke you?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Ile do my beſt endeuour to multiply, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Could you not make 'em two hundred?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: No by my faith.—

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.l: Peace, ile rather be confin'd in the hundred & fifty.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: Come ee'n much about this time, when Tauerns giue vp their Ghoſts, and Gentlemen are in their firſt caſt.—

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Ile obſerue the ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p:
And doe but whirle the Ring a'th doore once about,
my maid-ſeruant ſhal be taught to vnderſtand the language.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Inough my ſweet Reuenew.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Good reſt my effectuall pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Come hither Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What makes your honour breake ſo earely?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A toy, I haue a toy.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: A toy my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Before thou layeſt thy wrath vpon the duke,— be aduiz'd.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: I, I, I warran you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Nay, giue my words honour, heare me,
Ile ſtriue to bring this Act into ſuch forme,
And credite amongſt men, they ſhall ſuppoſe.
Nay verily beleeue the Prince his ſonne,
To be the plotter of his Fathers murther.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Oh that were infinitely admirable!

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Wert not, it pleaſeth me beyond my bliſſe:

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Then if his ſonne meet death as he returnes,
Or by my hired Inſtruments turne vp,
The generall voice will crie—O happy vengeance!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: O bleſſed vengeance!

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I, ile turn my braine
Into a thouſand vſes, Tire my inuentions,
Make my blood ſicke with ſtudie, and mine eye
More hollow then my heart, but I will faſhion,
Nay I will faſhion it,—Canſt counterfet?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The Princes hand, more truly, moſt direct,
You ſhall admire it.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Neceſſarie miſchiefe.
Next to a woman, but more cloſe in ſecrets
Thou'rt all the kinred that my breaſt vouch ſafes,
Looke into me anon,—I muſt frame, and muſe, and
faſhion—

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Twas time to looke into thee, in whoſe heart
Treaſon growes ripe, and therefore fit to fall,
That ſlaue firſt ſinkes, whoſe enuie threatens all,
Now is his Venom at full height.

sp.speaker: 1 Voic.
sp.p: Lying, or being in the ſaid Countie in the Tenor and occupation aforeſaide.

sp.speaker: 2 Voyce.
sp.p: No more then, a writ of courſe vpon the matter of—

sp.speaker: 3. Ʋoice.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: 4. Voice.
sp.p: Oh o-o-o-yes Carlo Turbulenzo, appeare or looſe twentie marke in the ſuites.

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.p: Ha? whether haue my thoughts conueyed me? I am now within the Dizzie murmur of the law.

sp.speaker: 1 Ʋoyce.
sp.p: So that then, the cauſe being found cleere, vpon the laſt Scitation.

sp.speaker: 4 Voice.
sp.l: Carlo turbulenzo, Come into the Court.

div.stage: Enter Tangle w̄ith two after him.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Now, now, now, now, now, vpon my knees I praiſe Mercury the God of law, I haue two ſuits at iſſue, two ſuites at iſſue.

sp.l: Doe you heare ſir?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: I wil not heare, i'ue other buſines.
I beſeech you my learned Counſell.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Beſeech not me, beſeech not me, I am a mortall man, a Clyent as you are, beſeech not me.
I would doe all by your worſhips direction.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Then hang thy ſelfe.
Shall I take out a ſpeciall ſupplycauit.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Mad me not, torment me not, teare me not, youle giue me leaue to heare mine own cauſe, mine owne cauſe

sp.speaker: 1. Ʋoice.
sp.p: Nay moreouer, and farder—

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Well ſaid my Lawyer, well ſaide, well ſaide.

sp.speaker: 1. Ʋoice.
sp.p: All the opprobious ſpeeches that man could inuent all malicious inuectiues, called Wittoll to his face.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Thats I, thats I, thank you my learned counſell for your good remembrance: I hope I ſhall ouerthrowe him horſe and foote.

sp.l: Nay but good ſir.

sp.speaker: Tang:
sp.p: No more ſir, he that brings me happy newes firſt ile releeue firſt.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Sound executions rot thy cauſe and thee.

sp.speaker: Ta:
sp.p: I, I, I, pray ſo ſtill, pray ſo ſtill, theile thriue the better

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I wonder how this fellow keepes out madnes?
What ſtuffe his braines are made on?

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I ſuffer, I ſuffer,—till I here a iudgement.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What old Signior?

sp.speaker: Tan
sp.p: Prethee I will not knowe thee nowe, tis a buſie time, a buſie time with me.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What not me Signeur?

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Oh crie thee mercie, giue me thy hande,—fare thee well,—ha's no reliefe agen mee then,—his demurs will not help him, his Surſararaes wil but play the knaues with him.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: The Iuſtice: tis hee

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Haue I found thee yfaith? I thought where I ſhould ſmell thee out old Tangle.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: What old Signeur Iuſticer,—embrace me another time and you can poſſible: how do's all thy wiues children,—well? that's well ſaid yfayth.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Heare me olde Tangle.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Prethee doe not rauiſh me, let me goe.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I muſt vſe ſome of thy counſaile firſt.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Sirrah, I ha brought him to an Exigent▪ hark that's my cauſe, thats my cauſe yōder, I twind'g him, I twind'g him.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: My Neece is ſtolne away.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Ah, get mee a ne exeat Regno quickly, nay you muſt not ſtay vppo'nt, ide faine haue you gone.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: A ne exeat Regno, ile about it preſently,—adue.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: You ſeeke to catch her Iuſtice, ſheele catch you.
A iudgement, a iudgement.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: What, what, what?
Ouerthrowne, ouerthrowne, ouerthrowne.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Ha, a, a.
Newes, newes, newes.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: The diuell, the diuell, the diuell.
Twice Tangle's ouerthrowne, twice Tangles ouerthrowne.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Holde:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Now olde cheater of the Law,

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Pray giue me leaue to bee madde.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p:
Thou that haſt found ſuch ſweete pleaſure in
the vexation of others.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: May I not be mad in quiet?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Very Marrow, very manna to thee to be in law.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: Very ſirrop of Toades, and perſeru'd Adders.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Thou that haſt vext, and beggerd the whole
Parriſh, and made the honeſt Church wardens goe to
Lawe with the poores money.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Heare me, doe but heare me, I pronounce a terrible, horrible curſſe vpon you al—and wiſh you to my Atturney: ſee where a Praemunire comes a Dedimus poteſtatem, and that moſte Dreadful Execution, Excommunicato Capiendo, there's no baile to be taken, I ſhal rot in fifteene Iayles: make Dice of my bones, and let my Counſellors Sonne play away his Fathers money with e'm; may my bones reuenge my quarrell!— A Capias Cominus? heere, heere, heere, heere: quicklye dip your Quilles in my blood, off with my skin and write fourteen lines of a ſide—there's an honeſt conſcionable fellowe, he takes but ten ſhillinges of a Bellowes-mender—heere's another deales all with charitie, you ſhall giue him nothing, onely his wife an embrodered Pettycoate, a golde frindge for her taile, or a border for her head, ah ſirrha! you ſhall catch mee no more in the ſprindge of your Knaueries.
Follow, follow him ſtill, a little thing now ſets him forward.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: None can except againſt him, the mans mad,
And priuiledgd by the Moone, if he ſay true:
Leſſe madnes tis to ſpeake ſinne, then to doe.
This wretch that lou'd before, his foode, his ſtrife,
This puniſhment falles euen with his life.
His pleaſure was vexation, all his bliſſe
The torment of another.
Their heart, his health: their ſtarued hopes his ſtore,
Who ſo loues Law, dies either mad or poore.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: A miracle, a miracle!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How now Fidelio?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My Lord a miracle!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What iſt?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: I haue found
One quiet, ſuffering, and vnlawyer'd man.
An oppoſite, a very Contrarie
To the olde turbulent fellowe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why hee's mad.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Mad, why he is in his right wits, could he be madder then he was, if he be any way altered from what hee was, tis for the better, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Well, but where's this wonder?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Tis comming my Lord: A man ſo truely a man, ſo indifferently a creature, vſing the world in his right nature but to tread vppon, one that would not bruſe, the cowardly eſt enemy to man, the worme, that dares not ſhow his malice till we are dead: nay my Lord, you will admire his temper! ſee where he comes, I promiſd your acquaintance, ſir
sp.l: Yon is the Gentleman I did commend for Temper.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Let me embrace you ſimply.
That's perfectly, and more in heart then hand:
Let affectation keepe at Court.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I, let it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Tis told me you loue quiet

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Aboue wealth.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I aboue life: I haue been wilde and raſh
Committed many and vnnaturall crimes,
Which I haue ſince repented.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Twa's well ſpent.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I was mad, ſtarke mad, nine yeares together.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I pray! as how?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Going to law, yfaith it made me mad.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: With the like frenzie not an houre ſince
An aged man was ſtrucke.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Alaſſe I pittie him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Hee's not worth pittying, for twa's ſtil his gladnes to be at variance.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Yet a mans worth pittie,
My quiet blood ha's bleſt me with this guift,
I haue cur'd ſome, and if his wits be not
Too deepely cut, I will aſſay to helpe e'm.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Sufferance does teach you pittie.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Maiſter, Maiſter, your abhominable next neighbor came into the houſe, being halfe in drink, and tooke away your beſt Carpet.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Has hee it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Alaſſe ſir:

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Let him goe, trouble him not, lock the doore quietly after him, and haue a ſafer care who comes in next.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: But ſir, might I aduize you, in ſuch a cauſe as this, a man might bouldlye, nay▪ with conſcience goe to Law.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Oh, ile giue him the table too firſt. Better indure a fiſt then a ſharpe ſword: I had rather they ſhould pull off my cloathes then flea of my skin, and hang that on mine enemies hedge.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why, for ſuch good cauſes was the law ordaind:

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: True, and in it ſelfe tis glorious and deuine,
Law is the verie Maiſter peece of heauen:
But ſee yonder.
Ther's many Clowdes betweene the ſunne and vs,
There's too much cloath before we ſee the Law:

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'me content with that anſwere, be milde ſtill,
Tis honour to forgiue thoſe you could kill.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: There doe I keepe.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Reach me your hand, I loue you,
And you ſhall knowe me better.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: Tis my ſute.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: The night growes deepe—and—

sp.speaker: 1 Off:
sp.l: Come away, this way, this way.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Who be thoſe? ſtand cloſe a little.

div.stage: Iars the Ring of the Doore, the Maide enters catches him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Oh, y'are come as well as ere you came in your life, my Maiſter's new gone to bed, giue me your Knightly hand, I muſt leade you into the blind Parlor, my miſtris will be downe to you preſentlye.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: I tell you our ſafeſt courſe will bee to arreſt him when hee comes out a'th Tauerne: for then he will bee halfe drunke, and will not ſtand vppon his weapon.

sp.l: Our ſafeſt courſe indeede, for hee will drawe.

sp.p: That he will, though he put it vp agen, which is more of his courteſie, then of our deſeruing.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: The world is nothing but vexation,
Spite and vncharitable Action.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Did you ſee the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Where ſhould he be, it may be hee's paſt by,
Good ſir, lets ouertake him.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Here ſir, now you are there ſir, ſheele come downe to you inſtantlye, I muſt not ſtay with you, my Miſtris would be iealous, you muſt doe nothing to me, my miſtris would finde it quickly.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: S'foot whether am I led? brought in byth hand? I hope it can bee no harme to ſtay for a woman, tho indeede they were neuer more dangerous, I haue ventured heatherto and ſafe, and I muſt venture to ſtay now, this ſhould be a faire Rome, but I ſee it not, the blinde Parlor cal's ſhee it?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Where art thou, O my Knight!

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Your Knight, I am the Dukes knight.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: I ſay you'r my knight, for I'me ſure I paid for you

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Paid for you hum,—S'foot a light.—

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Now out vpon the Marmoſet, haſt thou ſeru'd me ſo long, and offer to bring in a Candle?

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.p: Faire Roome, villanous face, and worſe woman, I ha learnt ſomething by a glimpſe ath Candle:

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: How hapned it you came ſo ſoone, I lookt not for you theſe two howers: yet as the ſweete chance is, you came as well as a thing coulde come, for my huſ: band's newly brought a bed.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: And what ha's Ioue ſent him?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Hee nere ſent him any thing ſince I knewe him, hee's a man of a bad nature to his wife, none but his Maides can thriue vnder him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Out vpon him.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I, iudge whether I haue a cauſe to be a Curtezan or no? to doe as I doe, an elderly fellow as hee is, if hee were marryed to a young Virgin, hee were able to breake her heart, tho he could breake nothing elſe: here, here, there's iuſt a hundred and fiftie, but I ſtole e'm ſo hardlye from him, twold ee'ne haue grieud you to haue ſeene it.

sp.speaker: Phoe
sp.l: So twould yfaith.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Therefore prethee my ſweete pleaſure, doe not keepe company ſo much, how doe you thinke I am able to maintaine you? though I bee a Iewellers wife, Iewells are like women, they riſe & fal, we muſt be content to looſe ſometimes, to gaine often, but you'r content alwaies to looſe, and neuer to gaine: what need you ride with a Footeman before you?

sp.speaker: Phoe:
sp.l: Oh thats the grace,

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.p: The grace? tis ſufficient grace that y'aue a Horſe to ride vpon, you ſhould thinke thus with your ſelfe euery time you goe to bed if my head were laide, what would become of that horſe? he would runne a bad race then as well as his Maiſter.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Nay, and you giue me money to chide me:—

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.p: No, if it were as much more, I would thinke it foule ſcorne to chide you, I aduiſe you to be thrifty, to take the time now, while you haue it, you ſhall ſildome get ſuch an other foole as I am, I warrant you: why there's Mettrezza Auriola keepes her loue with halfe the coſt that I am at, her friend can goe a foote like a good Husband, walke in woſted Stockings, and enquire for the Six-penny ordinarie.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Pox on't, and would you haue me ſo baſe?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: No, I would not haue you ſo baſe neither: but now and then, when you keep your Chamber, you might let your Footeman out for eighteen pence a day, a great releefe at yeares end I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: The age muſt needs be foule when vice reformes it.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Nay, I'ue a greater quarrell to you yet.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Yfaith, what iſt?

sp.speaker: Iewe.
sp.p: You made me beleeue at firſt the Prince had you in great eſtimation, and would not offer to Trauaile without you, nay, that he could not trauaile without your Direction and intelligence.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I'me ſorrie I ſaide ſo yfaith, but ſure I was ouerflowen when I ſpoke it, I could nere ha ſaide it elſe.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Nay more, you ſwore to me, that you were the firſt that taught him to ride a greate horſe, and tread the Ring with agilitie.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: By my troth I muſt needes confeſſe I ſwore a great lye in that, & I was a villain to doe it, for I could nere ride greate horſe in my life.

sp.speaker: Iewl.
sp.p:
Why loe, who would loue you now but a Cittizens wife? so inconſtant, ſo for ſworne: you ſay women are falſe Creatures, but take away men, and thei'd bee honeſter then you—Nay laſt of all, which offends me moſte of all, you tolde me you covld countenance me at Court, and you knowe wee eſteeme a friend there, more
worth then a Husband heere.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: What I ſpake of that. Lady, ile maintaine.

sp.speaker: Iew:
sp.l: You maintaine? you ſeene it court?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Why by this Diamond—

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Oh take heede, you cannot haue that, tis alwaies in the eye of my huſband.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I proteſt I will not keepe it, but onely vſe it for th is vertue, as a token to fetch you,& approue my power, where you ſhall not onely ye bee receiued, but made knowne to the beſt and chiefeſt.

sp.speaker: Iewel.
sp.l: Oh are you true?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Let me looſe my Reuenewe elſe.

sp.speaker: Iewl.
sp.p: That's your word indeede, and vppon that condition take it this kiſſe and my loue for euer.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Ynough.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Giue me thy hand, ile leade thee foorth.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I'me ſicke of al profeſſions, my thoughts burne:
He trauailes beſt, that knowes when to returne.

div.stage: Enter Knight, two Officers after him.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: Adue, farwell, to bed you, I to my ſweete Cittybird, my precious Reuennew, the verie thought of a hundred & fiftie Angels, encreaſes Oyle and Spirit, ho:

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: I arreſt you ſir.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: You haue made vs wayte a goodly time for you, haue you not thinke you? you are in your Rowſes & Mulwines a poxe on you: and haue no care of poore Officers ſtaying for you.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.p: I drunk but one health I proteſt, but I could void it now: at whoſe ſute I pra'y?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: At the ſute of him that makes ſuits, your Taylor,

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Why, he made me the laſt, this, this that I weare

sp.speaker: 1.Off.
sp.p:
Argo, nay, we haue bene Schollars I can tell you, wee could not haue beene knaues ſo ſoone elſe, for as in that notable Cittie cald London, ſtand two moſt famous Vniuerſities, Poultrie and Woodſtreet, where ſome are of
twentie yeares ſtanding, and haue tooke all their degrees from the Maiſters ſide, downe to the Miſtris ſide, the Hole, ſo in like manner—

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.p: Come, come, come, I had quite forgot the hundred and fiftie Angells.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: S'lid where be they?

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: Ile bring you to the ſight of e'm preſently.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: A notable Lad, and worthy to be arreſted: weele haue but ten for wayting, and then thou ſhalt chuſe whether thou wilt runne away from vs, or wee from thee.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: A match at running, come, come, followe me.

sp.speaker: 2 Off.
sp.l: Nay, feare not that.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Peace, you may happen to ſee toyes, but doe not ſee e'm.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Pah.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Thats the Doore.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: This?—knockes.

sp.speaker: Knight.
sp.l: S foote Officer you haue ſpoilde all already?

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.p: Why? you ſhall ſee, you ſhould haue but whirld the ring once about, and there's a Maid ſeruant brought vp to vnderſtand it.

sp.speaker: Maide.
sp.l: Whoſe at doore?

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.l: Als well againe: phiſt, tis I, tis I.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: You, what are you?

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Puh, where's thy miſtris?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Knigh.
sp.l: Tell her One, ſhe knowes who, her Pleaſure's heere, ſay.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Her Pleaſure? my miſtris ſcornes to be without her pleaſure at this time of night: is ſhee ſo voide of friendes thinke you? take that for thinking ſo: a Boxe

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: The hundred and fifty Angells are lockt vp in a Boxe, we ſhall not ſee e'm tonight.

sp.speaker: Knig.
sp.p:
Howe's this? am I vſde like a hundred pound
Gentleman? Do's my Reuennew forſake me? Dam me if euer I bee her pleaſure agen.— Well I muſt to priſon.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Goe prepare his roome, there's no remedie, ile bring him along, hee's tame enough now.

sp.speaker: Kni.
sp.l: Dare my Tailor preſume to vſe me in this ſort?
He ſteales and I muſt lie in priſon for't.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Come, come away ſir.

div.stage: Enter a Gentleman with a Drawer.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Art ſure thou ſaweſt him areſted Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: If mine eyes be ſober.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: And that's a queſtion, Maſſe here he goes, hee ſhall not goe to priſon, I haue a tricke ſhall baile him— away.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Geſſe, geſſe, who am I? who am I?

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Who the Diuell are you? let goe, — a Poxe on you, who are you? I haue loſt my priſoner.

sp.speaker: Gentle.
sp.p: Priſoner: I'ue miſtooke, I crie you heartily mercie, I haue done you infinite iniurie, a my troth I tooke you to be an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.p: Where were your eyes? could you not ſee I was an Officer, ſtop, ſtop, ſtop, ſtop.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Hah, hah, hah, ha.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Now Phoenix.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Now my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Let princely blood
Nouriſh our hopes, we being confuſion now.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: A terrible ſuddaine blow.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I:what day is this hangs ouer vs?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Bith Maſſe Monday.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: As I could wiſh my purpoſe will thriue beſt.
Twa's firſt my birthday, now my fortunes daie,
I ſee whome fate will raiſe needes neuer pray.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: How is the ayre?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Oh full of trouble.

sp.speaker: Prod:
sp.l: Do's not the skie looke pittiouſly blacke

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: As if twere hung with Rich mens Conſciences.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Ah, Stucke not a Comet like a Carbuckle
Vpon the dreadfull browe of Twelue laſt night?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Twelue, no twa's about one.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: About one moſt proper, for thats the Duke.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Well ſhifted from thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I could haue wiſht it betweene one and two
His ſonne and him.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Ile giue you comfort then.

sp.speaker: Prod,
sp.l: Prethee.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: There was a villanous Rauen ſeene laſt night,
Ouer the preſence chamber in hard Iuſtle
With a yong Eglet.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: A Rauen! that was I, what did the Rauen?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Mary my Lord the Rauen—to ſay truth,
I left the combat doubtfull.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: So tis ſtill,
For all is doubt, till the deed crowne the will,
Now bleſſe thy loynes with Freedome, wealth and honour,
Think all thy ſeede young Lords, and by this Acte.
Make a foote-cloathd poſteritie: now imagine
Thou ſeeſt thy Daughters with their traines borne vp,
Whome elſe deſpiſed want, may curſſe to whoredome,
And publike ſhames, which our ſtate neuer threate,
Shee's neuer lew'd, that is accounted great.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Ile alter that Court-Axiom▪ thus renewd,
Shee's neuer great, that is accounted lewde.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Stand cloſe, the preſence fils, heere, heere the place
And at his rizing, let his fall be baſe,
Beneath thy foote.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: How for his Guard my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: My golde and feare keepes with the chiefe of them

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: That's rarely well.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.p: Bould heedleſſe ſlaue, that dares attempt a deede which ſhall in peeces rend him my Lords both.

div.stage: Enter Luſsurioſo, and Infeſto two Lords.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: The happineſſe of the day.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Time my returning,
Treaſons haue ſtill the worſt, yet ſtill are ſpurning.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: The Duke!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I nere was gladder to beholde him.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: All. Long liue your Grace.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I do not like that ſtraine,
You know my age affoords not to liue long.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Spoke truer then you thinke for.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Beſtow that wiſh vpon the Prince our Sonne.

sp.speaker: Phoe,
sp.l: Nay, hee's not to liue long neither.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Him as the wealthie Treaſure of our hopes,
You as poſeſſion of our preſent Comfort,
Both in one heart, we reuerence in one.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Oh Treaſon of a good cōplexion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How now, what freſher newes fils the Courts eare?

sp.speaker: Prod,
sp.l: Fidelio!

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Glad Tydings to your Grace,
The prince is ſafe return'd, and in your Court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our ioy breakes at our eyes, the Prince is come!

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Soule qucking newes—pale vengeance to my blood.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: By me preſenting to your ſerious view,
A briefe of all his Trauailes.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Tis moſt welcome.
It ſhall be Deere and pretious to our Eye.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Hee Reades, i'me glad her reades.
Now take thyopportunitie, leaue that place.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: At hys firſt riſing let his fall be baſe.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: That muſt be altered now.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Which? his riſing or his fall?

sp.speaker: 1 rod.
sp.l: Art thou dull now?
Thou hear'ſt the Prince is come.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's heere my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I have got ſuch a large portion of knowledge, moſt worthy father, by the benefit of my Trauaile,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: And ſo he has no doubt my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That I am bolde now to warne you of Lord
sp.p: Proditors inſolent Treaſon, who has irreligiouſlye ſeduc'd a fellow, and cloſely conuaide him ee'n in the preſence-chaire to murder you:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Oh guiltie, guiltie.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What was that fell? whats hee?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I am the man.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: O ſlaue!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I haue no power to ſtrike,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I'me gone, i'me gone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let me admire heauen's wiſdome in my Sonne.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: I confeſſe it, he hyred me—

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: This is ſlaue,
Tis forg'd againſt mine honour and my life,
For in what part of reaſon can't appeare,
The Prince being Trauaild ſhould know Treaſons heere
Plaine counterfet—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dooſt thou make falſe our Sonne?

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: I know the prince will not affirme it.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: He can and will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Moſt iuſt, he may:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: A guard.

sp.speaker: Luſſ.
sp.l: We cannot but in loyall zeale our ſelues,
Lay hands on ſuch a Villaine.—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stay you, I finde you heere too.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: Vs my Lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Againſt Luſſurioſo and Infeſto, who not onelye moſte ryotouſlye conſume their houſes in vicious gaming, morgaging their liuings to the Merchant, wherby he with his heires enter vppon their lands, from whence this abuſe comes, that in ſhort time the Sonne of the Marchant has more Lordſhips then the Sonne of the Nobleman(which elſe was neuer borne to inheritance) but that which is more impious, they moſt adulterouſly traine out young Ladyes to Mid-night banquets, to the vtter defamation of their owne honors, & ridiculous abuſe of their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: How could the Prince heare that?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Moſt true my Lord.
My Conſcience is a witneſſe gainſt it ſelfe,
For to that execution of chaſt honour,
I was both hyr'd and led.

sp.speaker: Luſ.
sp.l: I hope the Prince out of his plentious wiſdome
Will not giue wrong to vs: as for this fellowe
Hee's poore, and cares not to be deſperate.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Iuſtice my Lord, I haue my Neece ſtolne from me
Sh'as left her Dowrie with me, but ſhee's gone,
Ide rather haue had her loue then her money I,
This, this, is one of them, Iuſtice my Lord:
I know him by his face, this is the Theefe.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Your grace may now in milder ſence perceiue
The wrong done to vs by this impudent wretch,
Who ha's his hand fixt at the throate of lawe,
And therefore durſt be deſperate of his life,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Peace, you'r too foule, your crime is in exceſſe:
One ſpot of him, makes not your Vlcers leſſe.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Duk
sp.l: Did your Violence force away his Neece?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: No my good Lord; ileſtil confeſſe whats truth.
I did remoue her from her many wrongs,
Which ſhee was pleaſd to leaue, they were ſo vilde.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What are you nam'd?

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Falſo my Lord, Iuſtice Falſo, i'me knowne by that name.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Falſo, you came fitly,
You are the verie next that followes here.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I hope ſo my Lord, my name is in all the Records
I can aſſure your good grace.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Againſt Iuſtice Falſo.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Ah.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Who hauing had the honeſt charge of his Neece committed to his truſt, by the laſt will and Teſtament of her deceaſed father, and with her all the power of his wealth, not onely againſt faith and conſcience detaines her Dowrie, but againſt Nature and humanity aſſaies to abuſe her body.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I'me preſent to affirme it my lou'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: How? what make I heere?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Eyther I muſt agree.
To loathed luſt, or deſpiſde beggery.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Are you the plaintiue here?

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: I my good Lord,
For fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Sildome comes a worſe—and moreouer not containde in this vice onelye, which is odious to much, but againſt the ſacred vſe of Iuſtice, maintaines three threeues to his men.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: Cuds me!

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p: Who onely take Purſſes in their Maiſters libertie, where if any one chance to be taken, he appeares before him in a falſe Beard, and owne of his owne fellows takes his examination.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.l: By my troth as true as can be, but hee ſhall not knowe on't.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.p:
And in the end will execute Iuſtice ſo cruellye vpon him, that hee will not truſt him in a priſon, but
commit him to his fellowes chamber.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: Can a man doe nothing i'the Countrey but tis told at Court? there's ſome buſie informing knaue abroad, a my life.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: That this is true, and theſe, and more my Lord.
(Be it vnder pardon ſpoken for mine owne)
Hee the diſeaſe of Iuſtice, theſe of honour,
And This of Loyaltie and Reuerence:
The vnſwept venome of the Pallace,

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Slaue!

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Behold the Prince to approoue it.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Oh, where?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Your Eyes keep with your Actions, both looke wrong.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: An infernall to my ſpirit.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My Lord the Prince:

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Tread me to duſt, thou in whō wonder keepes,
Behold the Serpent on his bellie creepes.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Ranckle not my foote, away.
Treaſon, we laugh at thy vain-labouring ſtrings,
Aboue the foote thou haſt no power ore Kings

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot with ſufficient ioy receiue thee,
And yet my ioye's too much,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: My royall Father,
To whoſe vnnaturall murther I was hir'd,
I thought it a more naturall courſe of trauaile,
And anſwering future expectation,
To leaue farre Countryes, and enquire mine owne,

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: To thee let Reuerence all her powers engage,
That art in youth a myracle to age.
State is but blindneſſ, ethou hadſt piercing Art,
We onely ſaw the knee; but thou the heart.
To thee then power and Dukedome we reſigne,
▪Hee's fit to raign, whoſe knowledge can refine:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Forbid it my obedience.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Our word's not vaine,
I know thee wiſe can'ſt both obey and raigne,
The reſt of life we dedicate to heauen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A happy and ſafe raigne to our new Duke.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Without your praiers ſafer, & happier: Fidelio.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: My royall Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Here take this Diamond:
You know the vertue on't, it can fetch vice:
Madam Caſtiza:

sp.speaker: Fid:
sp.l: She attends my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Place a guard neare vs.
Know you you fellow Ladie?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: My honours euill.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Torment agen?

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: So vgly are thy crimes,
Thine eye cannot endure 'em.
And that thy face may ſtand perpetually
Turn'd ſo from ours, and thy abhorred ſelfe,
Neither to threaten wracke of ſtate or credite,
An euerlaſting baniſhment ceaze on thee.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: Oh Fiend!

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Thy life is ſuch it is too bad to end.

sp.speaker: Prod.
sp.l: May thy Rule, life, and all that's in thee glad,
Haue as ſhort time—as thy begetting had.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Away, thy curſe is idle, the reſt are vnder reformation, and therefore vnder pardon.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Our duties ſhall turne edge vpon our crimes.

sp.speaker: Falſ.
sp.p: S'lid I was afraid of nothing, but that for my theeuerie, and bawderie I ſhould haue beene turnd to an Inkeeper: my daughter, I am aſham'd her worſhip ſhould ſee mee.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Who would not loue a friend at Court? what fine Galleries and roomes am I brought through? I had thoght my knight durſt not haue ſhown his face here, I.

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: Now mother of pride, and daughter of luſt, which is your friend now?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.p: I'me ſure you are not ſo vnprouided to be without a friend here, you'le pay enough for him firſt.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: This is the worſt roome that euer I came in.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I am your ſeruant Miſtris, know you not me!

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Your worſhip is to great for me to know: I'me but a ſmall timbred-woman when I'me out of my apparell, and dare not venture vpon greatnes.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Doe you denie me then? know you this purſe?

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: That purſe? O death has the Knight ſeru'd me ſo? giuen away my Fauours?

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Stand forth—thou one of thoſe, for whoſe cloſe luſts the plague neuer leaues the Citie.
Thou worſe then common: priuate, ſubtill harlot,
That doſt deceiue Three with one faigned lip,
Thy husband, the worlds eye, and the lawes whip.
Thy zeale is hot, for tis to luſt and frawde,
And doſt not dread to make thy booke thy Bawde,
Thou'rt curſſe enough to husbands il-got gaines,
For whom the Court reiects, his gold maintaines:
How deere and rare was Freedome wont to be,
Now few but are by their wiues copies free,
And brought to ſuch a head that now we ſee,
Citie and Suburbs weare one liuerie.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Tis long of thoſe, an't like your grace, that come in vpon vs, & wil neuer leaue marrying of our widdows till they make 'em all as free as their firſt husbands.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I perceiue you can ſhift a point well.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: Let me haue pardon I beſeech your grace, and Ile peach 'em all, all the cloſe women that are, and vpon my knowledge there's aboue fiue thouſand within the walls and the liberties.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: A band▪ they ſhall be ſent againſt the Turke, Infidels againſt Infidels.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.p: I will hereafter liue ſo modeſtly, I will not lie with mine owne husband, nor come neere a man in the way of honeſtie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Ile be her warrant my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: You are deceiu'd, you thinke y' are ſtil a Iuſtice.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: S'foot, worſe then I was before I kneeld, I am no Iuſtice now, I know I ſhall be ſome Inne-keeper at laſt.

sp.speaker: Iew.
sp.l: My father! tis mine owne father.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: I ſhould haue wondred elſe, luſt being ſo like.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.p: Her birth was kin to mine, ſhe may proue modeſt, for my ſake I beſeech you pardon her.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: For thy ſake Ile doe more, Fidelio hand her,
My fauours on you both, next all that wealth
Which was committed to that Periur'ds truſt.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I'me a begger now, worſe then an Inne-keeper.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Your Mittimus ſhall not ſerue, Ile ſet my ſelfe free with a Deliberandum, with a Deliberandum, marke you:

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What's he? a guard!

sp.speaker: Phoe.
sp.l: Vnder your ſufferance, worthy Father,
His harme is to himſelfe,
One that ha's lou'd vexation ſo much,
He cannot now be rid on't,
Has beene ſo long in ſuits that hee's Law-mad.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: A iudgement, I craue a iudgement, yea! Nunc pro tunc, Corruptione alicuius, I peept me a Rauen in the face, and I thought it had beene my Soliſter: oh the pens pricke me.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: And here comes he (wonder for temperance:)
Will take the cure vpon him.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: A bleſſing to this faire aſſembly.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.p: Awa, yile haue none ont, giue me an Audita querela, or a Teſtificandum, or a diſpatch in twelue Tearms, there's a bleſſing, there's a bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: You ſee the vnbounded rage of his diſeaſe,

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.p: Tis the foule fiend my Lord ha's got within him the reſt are faire to this, this breeds in Inke,
sp.l: And to that colour turnes the blood poſſeſt,
For inſtance, now your grace ſhall ſee him dreſt.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Ah hah I reioice then hee's puzled▪ & muzled too Iſt come to a Soepe corpus?

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: Ah, good ſir, this is for want of patience.

sp.speaker: Tang.
sp.l: That's a foole.
She neuer ſaw the Dogs and the Beares fight,
A Countrey thing.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: This is for lacke of grace,

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I'ue other buſineſſe, not ſo much idle time.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: You neuer ſay your prayers.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: I'me, aduizde by my learned counſel,

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: The power of my charme come o're thee,
Place by degrees thy wits before thee,
With ſilk en patience here I binde thee,
Not to moue till I vnwinde thee.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Yea! is my cauſe ſo muddy? do I ſticke, do I ſticke (faſt?
Aduocate heer's my hand, pull, art made of flint?
Wilt not helpe out?—alas there's nothing in't.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.p: Oh doe you ſluce the Veyne now?

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: Yes my honoured Lord.

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: Pray let me ſee the iſſue.

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: I therefore ſeeke to keepe it,—now burſt out
Thou filthy ſtreame of trouble, ſpite and doubt.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Oh an extent, a Proclamation, a Summons, a Recogniſance, a Tachment. and Iniunction, a Writ, a Seyſure, a Writ of praeiſement, an Abſolution, a Quietus eſt.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: You'r quieter I hope by ſo much Dreggs.
Beholde my Lord:

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: This, why it out frownes Inke:

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.p: Tis the diſeaſes Nature, the Fiends drinke.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.p: Oh ſicke, ſick, Signior Ply-fee, ſicke: lend me thy Nightcap, oh!

sp.speaker: Quie.
sp.l: The Balſum of a temperate braine,
I poure into this thirſtie veine,
And with this bleſſed oyle of quiet,
Which is ſo cheape, that few men buy it,
Thy ſtormie Temples I allay,
Thou ſhalt giue vp the Diuell and pray,
Forſake his works, the'yre foule and black,
And keepe thee bare in purſſe and backe.
No more ſhalt thou in paper quarrell,
To dreſſe vp Apes in good apparell.
He throwes his ſtocke, and all his flocke,
Into a ſwallowing gulfe,
That ſendes his Gooſe vnto his Foxe,
His Lambe vnto his Wolfe.
Keepe thy encreaſe,
And liue at peace,
For war's not equall to this battaile,
That eates but men this men and cattaile,
Therefore no more this combate chooſe:
Where he that wins, do's alwayes looſe,
And thoſe that gaine all, with this curſſe receiue it,
From fooles they get it, to their ſonnes they leaue it.

sp.speaker: Tan.
sp.l: Haile ſacred patience, I begin to feele
sp.p: I haue a Conſcience now, Truth in my words, Compaſſion in my hart, & aboue al, in my blood peaces muſick,
sp.l: Vſe me how you can,
You ſhall find me an honeſt-quiet man.
Oh, pardon, that I dare behold that face,
"Now I'ue leaſt law, I hope haue moſt grace,

sp.speaker: Phoen.
sp.l: We both admire the work-man and his peece:
Thus when all hearts are tunde to Honors ſtrings,
There is no muſicke to the Quire of Kings.

div.head: Prologus
div.l: THe markes and notions extant in each ſpirit,
Seald by th'induſtrious hand of art & merit,
Me thinkes appeare tranſparant (as the minde
By fence were bounded and might ſeeme confind
In th' externall eye) nor ſhall our tragicke muſe,
(If ſtrong hope faile not) need a coynd excuſe
But to thoſe marginall noates of yours do bring
(In following nombers from the learned ſpring)
Matter inſtructiue to inrich their parts
Where knowledge raignes crownd with it own deſarts,
Let ſuch with ſerious and impartiall hearing
Sound ſence, quicke ſight and iudgement neuer erring:
Suruay and cenſure the mineruall frame
Of his elaborate worke: and if his name
Merrit regard, and you vouchſafe to grace him
With eminent loue, or mongſtthoſe lawreats place him,
That with the magicke of ſweet poeſie,
Tranſfer Pernaſſus into Brittany,
He ſhall digeſt the Chaos of his braine,
To tunefull order and acquire a ſtraine,
Neere to the muſicke of the heauenly ſpheres,
To fit Times guard and rauiſh choyſeſt eares.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: FAme and Opinion like the two vvingd cap
On Hermes head, do lift all Poets vp:
Some, though deſeruing, yet aboue the Sphere
Of true impartiall cenſure, vvhoſe tun'd eare
Liſtens to all and can vvith iudgement ſay,
Others ſing vvell, though Thracian Orpheus play.
Our Muſe affects no excellence: if Fame tell
And through her ſhrill trompe at the Muſes well
(Where the thrice trebled bench of learning ſits
In ſtrict examination of others wits)
Sound ours, thogh humbly ſtraines, whoſe infant growth
Nor dares, nor will, with times hugd darlings quarrell,
Nor ſtand the lightning with the ſacred Lawrell)
We reſt content: yet thus farre may conceipt
Carry each labouring Artiſt, where the weight
Of his oyld taske is ouer, that his tongue
May like a father of his tender young
Speak natures language and not be withſtood,
When with our Muſe he ſaith, that This is good.

div.p: This Epilogue ſhould haue bene printed at the end of the booke, but there was no ſpare place for it.
